'''''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle''''' is a 2017 American [[Fantasy film|fantasy]] [[Adventure film|adventure]] [[comedy film]]<ref name="BBFC" /> directed by [[Jake Kasdan]] and written by [[Chris McKenna (writer)|Chris McKenna]], Erik Sommers, [[Scott Rosenberg]], and [[Jeff Pinkner]], based on a story by McKenna. Part of the [[Jumanji (franchise)|''Jumanji'' franchise]], the film is a [[sequel]] to the 1995 ''[[Jumanji]]'', which was based on the 1981 [[Jumanji (picture book)|children's book of the same name]] by [[Chris Van Allsburg]]. It pays tribute to [[Robin Williams]], the star of the first film, by mentioning his character's name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/film/2017-12-20/jumanji-2017-robin-williams-reference/|title=There's a touching tribute to Robin Williams in the new Jumanji film|work=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[Immediate Media Company]]|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=April 23, 2018|last=Fullerton|first=Huw|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330165052/http://www.radiotimes.com/news/film/2017-12-20/jumanji-2017-robin-williams-reference/|archive-date=2018-03-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> In addition, a replica of the {{boardgloss|piece|board game piece}} used by Williams's character also appears as a clue for the Jumanji game's new players. The film stars [[Dwayne Johnson]], [[Jack Black]], [[Kevin Hart]], [[Karen Gillan]], [[Nick Jonas]], and [[Bobby Cannavale]]. Set twenty-one years after ''Jumanji'', it follows four teenagers who are transported into the [[video game]] world of Jumanji and play as their [[Avatar (computing)|chosen characters]]. Joining another player, they must overcome the game's magical power to win and return home.
[[Principal photography]] began in [[Honolulu]] in September 2016 and ended in [[Atlanta]] in December. ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' premiered at the [[Grand Rex]] in [[Paris]] on December 5, 2017, and was theatrically released in the United States on December 20 in [[RealD 3D]] and [[IMAX]], by [[Sony Pictures Releasing]] under its [[Columbia Pictures]] label; unlike its predecessor, which was distributed by [[Tristar Pictures]]. The film received generally positive reviews from critics, who called it a "pleasant surprise" and praised the cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-is-certified-fresh/|title=Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is Certified Fresh|date=December 21, 2017|accessdate=December 21, 2017|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|last=Giles|first=Jeff|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180111074035/https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-is-certified-fresh/|archive-date=2018-01-11|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> It grossed over $962{{nbsp}}million worldwide, becoming the [[2017 in film#Highest-grossing films|fifth-highest-grossing film of 2017]] and the [[List of highest-grossing films#Highest-grossing films|42nd-highest-grossing film of all time]].
A sequel is scheduled to be released on December 13, 2019.
== Plot == <!-- NOTE: The plot summary is currently 694 words long, which is within the maximum permitted length. Please do not alter it or make it unnecessarily longer without first discussing and gaining consensus on the article's talk page. The plot summary does NOT intend to reproduce the experience of watching, nor is it meant to cover EVERY detail. It should serve as an overview of the major plot elements and events. PER WP:FILMPLOT, PLOT SUMMARIES FOR FEATURE FILMS AND TELEVISION SERIES SHOULD BE BETWEEN 400 AND 700 WORDS. See "Wikipedia:How to write a plot summary" (WP:PLOTSUM) for general guidelines.--> In 1996 in Brantford, [[New Hampshire]], teenager Alex Vreeke is given the Jumanji [[board game]] by his father, who found it on a beach. Uninterested, he sets the game aside. That night, it transforms into a [[video game]] [[ROM cartridge|cartridge]] which catches Alex's attention when he is awakened by the Jumanji drum beats. When he begins playing it, he disappears into the game.
Twenty years later,<!-- The film set is 2016, do not remove it. It specifically says in the movie --> four students at Brantford High School are sentenced to detention: Spencer Gilpin and his former friend Anthony "Fridge" Johnson for cheating, Bethany Walker for making a phone call during an English test, and Martha Kaply for refusing to participate in gym class and insulting her teacher. In the school basement, where they are serving their detention, Fridge discovers Alex's discarded video-game system, and he and Spencer decide to play. Although it has five [[Avatar (computing)|playable characters]], they are unable to select the first one, so they choose two others, and convince the girls to play as the remaining two. When Spencer presses "Start", they are transported into the game.
They land in a jungle, in the forms of their game avatars. Spencer is a tough, muscular explorer and archaeologist named Dr. Smolder Bravestone; Fridge is a diminutive zoologist named Franklin "Mouse" Finbar; Bethany is an overweight male cartographer named Professor Shelly Oberon; and Martha is a female commando and martial arts expert named Ruby Roundhouse. They each have three lives marked on their arms and Bethany immediately loses one after being eaten by a hippo. Spencer deduces that if they lose all three, they die for real.
They learn the game's story from [[Non-player character|NPC]] Nigel: corrupt archeologist Russel Van Pelt stole the Jaguar's Eye, a magic jewel, from its shrine, cursing Jumanji. Nigel escaped Van Pelt with the jewel, and the players must return it to a jaguar statue and call "Jumanji" to lift the curse. Nigel warns them that Van Pelt will stop at nothing to retrieve the jewel, which gives him control of Jumanji's animals. They begin tackling the game's increasingly-difficult "levels", losing lives as they do so. The four are rescued by Alex, the missing fifth player, whose avatar is pilot Jefferson "Seaplane" McDonough. Taking shelter in a jungle house built by the game's previous player Alan Parrish, Alex believes that he has been in the game for a few months and is distressed to learn that it is really twenty years. The newcomers vow to help him return home. They break into a transportation shed, commandeering a [[helicopter]] to fly to the jaguar statue and return the jewel, but Fridge drops the jewel into a herd of white rhinoceros. Spencer sacrifices one of Fridge's lives, pushing him out of the helicopter as a distraction, and retrieves the jewel. Alex loses his last life when a mosquito bites him, but Bethany performs CPR and transfers one of her lives to him.
At the statue, the players are surrounded by a pack of jaguars and Van Pelt's forces. They outmaneuver their opposition while Spencer and Martha race to the statue. Van Pelt confronts Martha and demands the jewel, but she purposely gets a snake to bite her, allowing her to respawn and to get the jewel to Spencer. With the players on their last lives, they end the game, with Van Pelt disintegrating into a bunch of [[rat]]s, and return to the school basement, though without Alex. They find the formerly-dilapidated Vreeke home restored and decorated for a Christmas family gathering. An adult Alex arrives, having returned to 1996 when the game ended. Now married with children, he reveals he named his eldest daughter after Bethany out of gratitude for saving his life.
Spencer and Fridge reconcile, Bethany begins caring for others more than herself and plans a summer wilderness backpacking adventure, Martha and Spencer become romantically involved and the four are now friends after their experiences in the game. When they hear Jumanji's drumbeats, they bring the game behind the school and Fridge destroys it to prevent anyone from playing it again.
==Cast== * [[Dwayne Johnson]] as Dr. Smolder Bravestone, Spencer's avatar: a strong, confident [[Archaeology|archaeologist]] and explorer, and the leader of the team. ** [[Alex Wolff]] as Spencer Gilpin, a nerdy student at Brantford High School. His experience as Smolder Bravestone helps him cope with his anxiety and [[Panphobia|panphobia]] and develop assertiveness. * [[Jack Black]] as Professor Sheldon "Shelly" Oberon, Bethany's avatar: a [[Cartography|cartographer]], [[Cryptanalysis|cryptographer]], [[Archaeology|archaeologist]], and [[Paleontology|paleontologist]]. ** [[Madison Iseman]] as Bethany Walker, a pretty, popular, [[egocentrism|self-centered]] teenage girl at Brantford High School * [[Kevin Hart]] as Franklin "Mouse" Finbar, Fridge's avatar: a diminutive [[Zoology|zoologist]] and weapons specialist ** [[Ser'Darius Blain]] as Anthony "Fridge" Johnson, a Brantford High School football jock coasting on his athletic prowess who cares more about dating than studying * [[Karen Gillan]] as Ruby Roundhouse, Martha's avatar: a martial artist and [[Capoeira in popular culture|dance fighter]] ** [[Morgan Turner]] as Martha Kaply, a shy and cynical intellectual at Brantford High School * [[Nick Jonas]] as Jefferson "Seaplane" McDonough, Alex Vreeke's avatar: a young [[aircraft pilot]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/06/29/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-trailer/ |title=Dwayne Johnson, Jack Black go wild in first ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' trailer |last=Coggan |first=Devan |date=June 29, 2017 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=June 29, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629145040/http://ew.com/movies/2017/06/29/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-trailer/ |archivedate=June 29, 2017 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ** Mason Guccione as Alex Vreeke, a teenage gamer who was trapped inside the Jumanji video game in 1996 ** [[Colin Hanks]] as Alex as an adult two decades later * [[Bobby Cannavale]] as Russel Van Pelt, Bravestone's former partner and the game's villain. He tries to retrieve the Jaguar's Eye, whose power possesses him. * [[Rhys Darby]] as Nigel Billingsley, the players' main in-game guide * [[Marc Evan Jackson]] as Principal Bentley, who makes Spencer, Bethany, Fridge, and Martha clean up the basement as part of their detention * Carlease Burke as Miss Mathers, Spencer and Fridge's history teacher * Sean Buxton as Mr. Vreeke, Alex's father, who discovers the Jumanji game in 1996 ** [[Tim Matheson]] (uncredited) as Old Man Vreeke * [[Maribeth Monroe]] as Bethany's English Teacher * [[Missi Pyle]] as Coach Webb, Martha, Spencer and Bethany's gym teacher * Kat Altman as Lucinda, Bethany's friend * [[Marin Hinkle]] as Mrs. Gilpin, Spencer's mother * Tracey Bonner as Mrs. Johnson, Fridge's mother * Natasha Charles Parker as Mrs. Walker, Bethany's mother * Michael Shacket as Fussfeld, a friend of Spencer's at Brantford High School who is infatuated with Bethany * [[William Tokarsky]] as a food vendor in the game * [[Rohan Chand]] as a boy at a bazaar in the game
==Production== ===Development=== In July 2012, rumors circulated that a remake of ''[[Jumanji]]'' was in development. In an interview with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', [[Columbia Pictures]] president [[Doug Belgrad]] said: "We're going to try and reimagine ''Jumanji'' and update it for the present."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whatstrending.com/2012/07/jumanji-reboot-works/|title= 'Jumanji' Reboot In The Works|work=[[What's Trending]]|publisher=Disrupt/Group|last=Hernandez|first=Esteban L.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024140753/http://whatstrending.com/2012/07/jumanji-reboot-works/|archivedate=October 24, 2013 |dead-url=yes |accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> On August 1, 2012, it was confirmed that Matthew Tolmach would produce the new version with William Teitler (who produced the original film).<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.movieweb.com/jumanji-reboot-lands-producer-matthew-tolmach |title=Jumanji Reboot Lands Producer Matthew Tolmach|work=[[MovieWeb]] |publisher=Watchr Media |accessdate=April 23, 2018 | date= August 1, 2012 |first= Brian |last= Gallagher|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227020718/http://www.movieweb.com/jumanji-reboot-lands-producer-matthew-tolmach|archivedate=December 27, 2014 }}</ref>
In August 2015, [[Sony Pictures|Sony Pictures Entertainment]] announced that the film was scheduled for release on December 25, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sony Pictures Dates 16 Films Through 2019!|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/468725-sony-pictures-dates-16-films|accessdate=October 25, 2015|publisher=[[CraveOnline Media]]|work=ComingSoon.net|date=August 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150807171320/http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/468725-sony-pictures-dates-16-films|archivedate=August 7, 2015|df=mdy-all|author=CS}}</ref> Online reception to the news was negative, with some saying that the announcement came too soon after the August 2014 death of [[Robin Williams]] (who played Alan Parrish in the original film).<ref>{{cite web|last=Hanks|first=Henry|title=They're remaking 'Jumanji,' and the Internet rage is real|date=August 7, 2015|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/06/entertainment/jumanji-reboot-feat/|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=October 25, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151023062029/http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/06/entertainment/jumanji-reboot-feat/|archivedate=October 23, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Pulver|first=Andrew|title='Is nothing sacred?': Twitter responds to news of Jumanji remake|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/aug/07/is-nothing-sacred-twitter-responds-to-news-of-jumanji-remake|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=August 7, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025003024/http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/aug/07/is-nothing-sacred-twitter-responds-to-news-of-jumanji-remake|archivedate=October 25, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The announcement was criticized by [[Bradley Pierce]] (who played Peter Shepherd in ''Jumanji'') and by ''[[E! News]]'', which called the remake "unnecessary and kind of insulting".<ref>{{cite web|last=Mullins|first=Jenna|title=People Are Livid About This Jumanji Remake, and We Don't Blame Them|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/683862/people-are-livid-about-this-jumanji-remake-and-we-don-t-blame-them|publisher=[[E!]]|work=[[E! News]]|date=August 6, 2015|accessdate=October 25, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029204838/http://www.eonline.com/news/683862/people-are-livid-about-this-jumanji-remake-and-we-don-t-blame-them|archivedate=October 29, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Faherty|first=Allanah|title=Don't Worry Internet, Star of the Original 'Jumanji' Movie Doesn't Believe Sony Should Reboot the Film Either|url=http://moviepilot.com/posts/2015/08/10/don-t-worry-internet-star-of-the-original-jumanji-movie-doesn-t-believe-sony-should-reboot-the-film-either-3457820?lt_source=external,manual|work=[[Moviepilot]]|accessdate=October 25, 2015|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{dead link|fix-attempted=yes|date=April 2018}}</ref> On October 23, 2015, [[Scott Rosenberg]] was hired to rewrite the script for the film, whose production was a high priority for the studio.<ref>{{cite news|last=Busch|first=Anita|title=Scott Rosenberg Comes Aboard 'Jumanji' For Columbia Pictures|url=http://deadline.com/2015/10/scott-rosenberg-jumanji-columbia-pictures-1201592487/|accessdate=October 25, 2015|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=October 23, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025023623/http://deadline.com/2015/10/scott-rosenberg-jumanji-columbia-pictures-1201592487/|archivedate=October 25, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On January 14, 2016, ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' reported that [[Jake Kasdan]] had been hired to direct the film from a script by Rosenberg and [[Jeff Pinkner]] based on a draft by original writers [[Chris McKenna (writer)|Chris McKenna]] and Erik Sommers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Mike Jr.|title=Jake Kasdan To Helm 'Jumanji' Reboot For Sony|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/jumanji-jake-kasdan-reboot-sony-pictures-robin-williams-1201683408/|accessdate=January 16, 2016|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 14, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115071145/https://deadline.com/2016/01/jumanji-jake-kasdan-reboot-sony-pictures-robin-williams-1201683408/|archivedate=January 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In March 2017, during CinemaCon, it was announced that the film's complete title was ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle''. Its plot involved teenagers cleaning out a school's basement who find a [[Retrogaming|vintage video-game]] version of ''Jumanji'' and are sucked into the first film's jungle setting. Although fans debated whether the film was a sequel or a [[Reboot (fiction)|reboot]], the second trailer (released on September 20, 2017) indicated that the sequel is set 21 years after the first. Dwayne Johnson noted that the film was inspired by classic [[1990s in video gaming|video games of the 1990s]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Jumanji Inspired By 1990s Video Games |url=https://screenrant.com/jumanji-tone-video-games-1990s/ |work=[[Screen Rant]] |date=13 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=How Video Games From The 1990s Are Influencing Jumanji, According To The Rock |url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/1713130/how-video-games-from-the-1990s-are-influencing-jumanji-according-to-the-rock |work=Cinema Blend |date=October 12, 2017 |access-date=2018-11-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171223044825/https://www.cinemablend.com/news/1713130/how-video-games-from-the-1990s-are-influencing-jumanji-according-to-the-rock |archive-date=2017-12-23 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>

news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Kevin Hart, Dwayne Johnson Circling 'Jumanji' Reimagining (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/jumanji-remake-kevin-hart-dwayne-johnson-1201725642/|accessdate=April 25, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=April 15, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424145032/http://variety.com/2016/film/news/jumanji-remake-kevin-hart-dwayne-johnson-1201725642/|archivedate=April 24, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Later in the month, Johnson confirmed his casting on [[Instagram]].<ref name=JohnsonCast>{{cite news|last=Evry|first=Max|title=Dwayne Johnson Officially Boards Jumanji Remake|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/679261-dwayne-johnson-officially-boards-jumanji-remake|accessdate=April 25, 2016|work=ComingSoon.net|publisher=[[CraveOnline Media]]|date=April 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In July, it was reported that [[Nick Jonas]] had joined the film's cast with Johnson, Hart, and [[Jack Black]].<ref name="JonasCast">{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Mike Jr.|title=Nick Jonas In Talks To Join 'Jumanji' Movie|url=http://deadline.com/2016/07/nick-jonas-jumanji-movie-casting-1201794166/|accessdate=July 29, 2016|work=[[Deadline following month, Johnson said that the film would not be a reboot but a continuation of the 1995 film;<ref>{{cite news|title=Dwayne Johnson Says Jumanji Will Not be a Reboot|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/759653-dwayne-johnson-says-jumanji-will-not-be-a-reboot|accessdate=August 22, 2016|work=ComingSoon.net|publisher=[[CraveOnline Media]]|date=August 21, Two days later, [[Rhys Darby]] was cast as Nigel Billingsley, Morgan Turner as Martha Kaply, and [[Alex Wolff]] as Spencer Gilpin.<ref name="Sep2016D">{{cite news|last=N'Duka|first=Amanda|title=Sony's 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on September 19, 2016, in [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]],<ref name="Apr2016V"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Jumanji Starts Production and The Rock Shares a Set Video|url=http://collider.com/jumanji-starts-production-the-rock-dwayne-johnson-set-video/|accessdate=September 16, 2016|work=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|publisher=Complex Media|date=September 15, 2016|last=Trumbore|first=Dave|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916025445/http://collider.com/jumanji-starts-production-the-rock-dwayne-johnson-set-video/|archive-date=2016-09-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> primarily at the Kualoa Ranch nature reserve.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/travel/usa-canada/new-jumanji-film-filming-locations-11816406|title=How to explore the real Jumanji jungle where you can have your own adventure|last=Delahaye|first=Julie|date=January 8, 2018|work=[[The Daily Mirror]]|publisher=MGN|accessdate=March 11, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116095553/https://www.mirror.co.uk/travel/usa-canada/new-jumanji-film-filming-locations-11816406|archive-date=2018-01-16|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The film wrapped on December 8 in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web|title="Jumanji" with Kevin Hart, Jack Black and The Rock wraps in Atlanta|url=http://buzz.blog.ajc.com/2016/12/08/jumanji-with-kevin-hart-jack-black-and-the-rock-wraps-in-atlanta/|work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|date=December 8, 2016|accessdate=December 9, 2017|last=Brett|first=Jennifer|publisher=[[Cox Media Group]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421094737/http://buzz.blog.ajc.com/2016/12/08/jumanji-with-kevin-hart-jack-black-and-the-rock-wraps-in-atlanta/|archive-date=2018-04-21|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===Music=== {{Main|Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle (soundtrack)}} [[James Newton Howard]] was originally signed to compose the film's score,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2016/10/06/james-newton-howard-to-score-jake-kasdans-jumanji-sequel/|title=James Newton Howard to Score Jake Kasdan's 'Jumanji' Sequel|author=filmmusicreporter|website=Film Music Reporter|date=October 6, 2016|accessdate=October 6, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009134444/http://filmmusicreporter.com/2016/10/06/james-newton-howard-to-score-jake-kasdans-jumanji-sequel/|archivedate=October 9, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> he was replaced by [[Henry Jackman]] when the film's release date was postponed six months.<ref name="JackmanScoresJumanji" /> The soundtrack was released digitally on 15 December 2017 by [[Sony Masterworks]].
==Release== In August 2015, Sony gave the film a release date of December 25, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kroll|first=Justin|title=Sony Dates 16 Films Including Two More 'Bad Boys' Sequels, 'Jumanji' Remake|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/sony-films-bad-boys-jennifer-lawrence-passengers-1201557242/|accessdate=October 25, 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=August 5, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013062027/http://variety.com/2015/film/news/sony-films-bad-boys-jennifer-lawrence-passengers-1201557242/|archivedate=October 13, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Since filming did not begin until September 2016, the release was pushed back to July 28 and then to December 20, 2017.<ref name=insight/>
On November 29, 2017, it was announced that [[Amazon Prime]] members in the United States would have early access to tickets for a December 8 screening of the film at select [[Regal Entertainment Group|Regal]], [[National Amusements]], [[ArcLight Hollywood|ArcLight Cinemas]] and [[AMC Theatres|AMC]] theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-amazon-prime-early-screenings-marketing-1202216329/|title='Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle' To Swing In Early For Amazon Prime Members|first=Nancy|last=Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=November 29, 2017|accessdate=November 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171129143833/http://deadline.com/2017/11/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-amazon-prime-early-screenings-marketing-1202216329/|archive-date=2017-11-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The screenings sold out at 1,200 theaters and earned $1.9 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-amazon-prime-sneak-box-office-1202227292/|title='Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle' Amazon Prime Sneaks Sell Out Grossing Near $2M|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=December 14, 2017|accessdate=December 15, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171214235449/http://deadline.com/2017/12/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-amazon-prime-sneak-box-office-1202227292/|archive-date=2017-12-14|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The film was released on [[IMAX]] 2D on January 12, 2018.
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' grossed $404.5 million in the United States and Canada and $557.6 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $962.1 million.<ref name=BOM/> On April 10, 2018, the film passed ''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'' ($403.7 million) to become Sony's highest-grossing film domestically. ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' calculated its net profit as $305.7 million when factoring all expenses and revenues, making it 2017's fourth-most-profitable release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-box-office-profit-1202351461/|title=No. 4 'Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle' Box Office Profits – 2017 Most Valuable Blockbuster Tournament|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=March 26, 2018|accessdate=March 26, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180327005923/http://deadline.com/2018/03/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-box-office-profit-1202351461/|archive-date=2018-03-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
In the U.S. and Canada, the film was released on December 20, 2017 with ''[[The Greatest Showman]]'' and was projected to gross about $60 million from 3,765 theaters in its six-day opening weekend; the studio predicted a $45 million debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/2017-domestic-box-office-the-last-jedi-2016-all-time-record-1202215287/|title=Does 2017's Domestic Box Office Stand A Chance To Eclipse Last Year's All-Time $11.4B Record?|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=November 28, 2017|accessdate=November 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128220952/https://deadline.com/2017/11/2017-domestic-box-office-the-last-jedi-2016-all-time-record-1202215287/|archive-date=2017-11-28|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jumanji-welcome-jungle-tracking-strong-60m-christmas-debut-1063035|title='Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' Tracking for Strong $60M Christmas Debut|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=November 30, 2017|accessdate=November 30, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171130175857/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jumanji-welcome-jungle-tracking-strong-60m-christmas-debut-1063035|archive-date=2017-11-30|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> It earned $7.2 million on its first day and $7.6 million on its second day. Over the three-day weekend, the film grossed $36.2 million (for a six-day total of $71.9 million), finishing second at the box office behind ''[[Star Wars: The Last Jedi]]''.<ref name=opening>{{Cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/12/last-jedi-dwayne-johnson-jumanji-zac-efron-greatest-showman-box-office-1202230784/|title='Last Jedi' Now At $99M, 'Jumanji' Huge At $72M+; 'All The Money In The World' Opens To $2.6M – Christmas Weekend|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=December 26, 2017|accessdate=December 26, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180223172216/http://deadline.com/2017/12/last-jedi-dwayne-johnson-jumanji-zac-efron-greatest-showman-box-office-1202230784/|archive-date=2018-02-23|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Its weekend-only earnings increased to $50.1 million during its second weekend, again finishing in second place at the box office.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/last-jedi-jumanji-new-years-weekend-box-office-2018-1202233711/|title='Last Jedi' Has Upper Hand Over 'Jumanji' In New Year's Weekend Duel As 2017 B.O. Closes With $11.1B – Monday Update|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=December 31, 2017|accessdate=January 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125193638/https://deadline.com/2018/01/last-jedi-jumanji-new-years-weekend-box-office-2018-1202233711/|archive-date=2018-01-25|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The 38.4 percent weekend-to-weekend increase was the fourth-largest for a film playing in over 3,000 theaters; ''The Greatest Showman'' set the record for best hold the same weekend.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/smallestdrops.htm?page=DROP3000&p=.htm|title=Smallest Second Weekend Drops: 1982-Present|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=January 3, 2018|publisher=[[IMDb]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180107160805/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/smallestdrops.htm?page=DROP3000&p=.htm|archive-date=2018-01-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2017/12/31/hugh-jackmans-the-greatest-showman-just-set-a-new-box-office-record/|title=Hugh Jackman's 'The Greatest Showman' Just Set A New Box Office Record|first=Scott|last=Mendelson|work=[[Forbes]]|date=December 31, 2017|accessdate=January 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171231170213/https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2017/12/31/hugh-jackmans-the-greatest-showman-just-set-a-new-box-office-record/|archive-date=2017-12-31|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The film passed ''Star Wars: The Last Jedi'' for the top spot the following weekend, declining 28.1 percent to $36 million,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/insidious-the-last-key-last-jedi-jumanji-weekend-box-office-1202236009/|title='Jumanji' Goes Wild With $36M; 'Insidious' Rises To $29M+ – Sunday AM B.O. Update|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 7, 2018|accessdate=January 7, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180107174859/http://deadline.com/2018/01/insidious-the-last-key-last-jedi-jumanji-weekend-box-office-1202236009/|archive-date=2018-01-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and finished first again the following week with $28.1 million (and a total of $35.2 million over the four-day [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day|MLK weekend]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/the-commuter-proud-mary-jumanji-paddington-2-mlk-weekend-box-office-1202241724/|title='Jumanji' Roars To $34M; 'The Post' Still The Most With $22M+; 'The Commuter' Punches $16M: MLK Weekend Box Office Update|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114020415/http://deadline.com/2018/01/the-commuter-proud-mary-jumanji-paddington-2-mlk-weekend-box-office-1202241724/|archive-date=2018-01-14|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' remained atop the box office for its third weekend, earning $19.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/den-of-thieves-12-strong-jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-weekend-box-office-1202262795/|title=January Slows As 'Jumanji' Takes No. 1 For 3rd Weekend With $19M To $20M; Older Guy Pics '12 Strong' & 'Den Of Thieves' In Mid-Teens|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 21, 2018|accessdate=February 2, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180204022918/https://deadline.com/2018/01/den-of-thieves-12-strong-jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-weekend-box-office-1202262795/|archive-date=2018-02-04|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
It again topped the box office for a fourth consecutive week (its sixth week overall in theatres) with $20 million, easily surpassing new releases ''[[12 Strong]]'' and ''[[Den of Thieves (film)|Den of Thieves]]'' (both films finished their entire run with box office lower than ''Jumanji: Welcome...'' grossed in its first 10 days).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/den-of-thieves-12-strong-jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-weekend-box-office-1202262795/|title=January Slows As 'Jumanji' Takes No. 1 For 3rd Weekend With $19M To $20M; Older Guy Pics '12 Strong' & 'Den Of Thieves' In Mid-Teens|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=January 21, 2018|accessdate=January 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121051949/http://deadline.com/2018/01/den-of-thieves-12-strong-jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-weekend-box-office-1202262795/|archive-date=2018-01-21|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The film continued to do well the following week, dropping 16 percent (to $16.4 million) and finishing second to ''[[Maze Runner: The Death Cure]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/maze-runner-death-cure-weekend-box-office-1202269925/|title=Fox Controls Close To 40% Of Weekend B.O. Led By 'Maze Runner' & Oscar Holdovers; 'Hostiles' Gallops Past $10M|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=January 28, 2018|accessdate=January 28, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127083806/http://deadline.com/2018/01/maze-runner-death-cure-weekend-box-office-1202269925/|archive-date=2018-01-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> before regaining the top spot for a fifth time the following weekend with $11.1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/maze-runner-winchester-jumanji-super-bowl-weekend-box-office-1202277031/|title='Jumanji' Poised To Be Dwayne Johnson's Highest Grossing Pic Of All-Time Stateside After Super Bowl Weekend Rebound|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=February 4, 2018|accessdate=February 4, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180203123939/http://deadline.com/2018/02/maze-runner-winchester-jumanji-super-bowl-weekend-box-office-1202277031/|archive-date=2018-02-03|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 77% based on 209 reviews and an average rating of 6.2/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' uses a charming cast and a humorous twist to offer an undemanding yet solidly entertaining update on its source material."<ref>{{cite web|title=Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle (2017)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jumanji_welcome_to_the_jungle|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|access-date=2017-12-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209034738/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jumanji_welcome_to_the_jungle|archive-date=2017-12-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 58 out of 100 based on 44 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/movie/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle|title=Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle Reviews|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|access-date=2018-10-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820020825/http://www.metacritic.com/movie/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle|archive-date=2018-08-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="Cinemascore">{{cite web|url=https://www.cinemascore.com|title=Cinemascore|work=cinemascore.com|access-date=2018-11-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102130540/https://www.cinemascore.com/|archive-date=2018-01-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
Dave White of ''[[TheWrap]]'' praised the cast and called the film a pleasant surprise: "''Jumanji: Welcome to The Jungle'' is the Christmas tentpole release that aims to please and succeeds, a funny family entertainment product that subverts more expectations than it was obligated to contractually".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thewrap.com/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-film-review-dwayne-johnson-kevin-hart-jack-black/|title='Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' Film Review: A Mainstream Moviegoing Miracle|work=[[TheWrap]]|date=December 19, 2017|accessdate=December 19, 2017|last=White|first=David|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220150617/https://www.thewrap.com/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-film-review-dwayne-johnson-kevin-hart-jack-black/|archive-date=2017-12-20|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> David Ehrlich of [[IndieWire]] gave the film a C grade, calling it unnecessary but mildly amusing: "''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' is further proof that even the stalest whiff of brand recognition has become preferable to originality. Only part of the blame for that belongs to the studios but after cannibalizing themselves for much of the last 20 years, Hollywood has clearly eaten their way down to the crumbs".<ref>{{cite web |first=David |last=Ehrlich |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/12/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-review-dwayne-johnson-jack-black-kevin-hart-karen-gillan-1201904969/ |title='Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' Review: A Robin Williams Relic Is Reborn as a Mildly Amusing Video Game Movie |work=[[IndieWire]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |date=December 8, 2017 |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209072600/http://www.indiewire.com/2017/12/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-review-dwayne-johnson-jack-black-kevin-hart-karen-gillan-1201904969/ |archive-date=2017-12-09 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> For ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', [[Owen Gleiberman]] wrote: "Excitement! Suspense! Childlike innocence! Ingeniously staged action set pieces! These are a few of the things you will not find, anywhere, in ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' ... It's supposed to be a board game come to life but really, it's just a bored game."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/reviews/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-review-dwayne-johnson-kevin-hart-1202633910/|title=Film Review: 'Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=December 8, 2017 |accessdate=December 9, 2017 |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |first=Owen |last=Gleiberman}}</ref>

==Home media== ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' was released on Digital HD on March 6, 2018 and on [[DVD]], [[Blu-ray]], and [[4K resolution|4K]] [[Ultra HD Blu-ray]] on March 20, although the film was still in theaters. The Blu-ray and digital versions include two additional featurettes: "Surviving the Jungle: Spectacular Stunts!" and "Book to Board Game to Big Screen & Beyond! Celebrating The Legacy of Jumanji".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mediaplaynews.com/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-on-home-video-in-march/|title='Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' on Home Video in March|first=John |last=Latchem|work=Media Play News|publisher=JCH Media|date=February 9, 2018|accessdate=March 11, 2018}}</ref>
==Sequel== [[Dwayne Johnson]], [[Jack Black]], and [[Nick Jonas]] discussed ''Jumanji 3''{{'s}} plot in interviews, including the possibility of the film exploring the origins of the game. According to [[Karen Gillan]], the alternate ending of ''Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle'' would have left the door open for another installment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/nick-jonas-interview-jumanji-3/|title=Nick Jonas Has A Funny Idea For The Next Jumanji Sequel|first=Rob|last=Keyes|work=[[Screen Rant]]|date=December 21, 2017|accessdate=April 23, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180609002805/https://screenrant.com/nick-jonas-interview-jumanji-3/|archive-date=2018-06-09|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/jumanji-3-jack-black-idea-sequel/|title=Jack Black Has A Great Idea For Jumanji 3|first=Matt|last=Dolloff|work=[[Screen Rant]]|date=December 22, 2017|accessdate=April 23, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180608221142/https://screenrant.com/jumanji-3-jack-black-idea-sequel/|archive-date=2018-06-08|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://screenrant.com/jumanji-3-casting/|title=Here's Who Jumanji's Stars Want to See in Jumanji 3|first=Christopher|last=Isaac|work=[[Screen Rant]]|date=December 25, 2017|accessdate=April 23, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611075927/https://screenrant.com/jumanji-3-casting/|archive-date=2018-06-11|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/the-jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-cast-have-jumanji-3-ideas-plus-an-alternate-ending-for-the-new-sequel/|title=The 'Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle' Cast Have 'Jumanji 3' Ideas, Plus an Alternate Ending for the New Sequel|first=Chris |last=Evangelista|work=[[/Film]]|date=December 27, 2017 |accessdate=April 23, 2018}}</ref> In February 2018, it was announced that Kasdan would direct the sequel, with Rosenberg and Pinkner again writing the script and Johnson, Hart, Black, Gillan and Jonas reprising their roles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-sequel-scott-rosenberg-jeff-pinkner-sony-dwayne-johnson-kevin-hart-jack-black-1202278493/|title=Scott Rosenberg & Jeff Pinkner To Write 'Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle' Sequel|first=Mike Jr.|last=Fleming|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=February 6, 2018|accessdate=February 6, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207134809/http://deadline.com/2018/02/jumanji-welcome-to-the-jungle-sequel-scott-rosenberg-jeff-pinkner-sony-dwayne-johnson-kevin-hart-jack-black-1202278493/|archive-date=2018-02-07|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> Filming will begin in January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/kevin-hart-night-school-tiffany-haddish-1202965158/|title=Kevin Hart on ‘Night School,’ the ‘Jumanji’ Sequel and Why He Wants to Direct|first=Rebecca|last=Rubin|date=2 October 2018|publisher=|access-date=2018-10-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181002222929/https://variety.com/2018/film/news/kevin-hart-night-school-tiffany-haddish-1202965158/|archive-date=2018-10-02|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> The film is slated to be released December 13, 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/jumanji/news/a860459/jumanji-sequel-release-date/|title=Dwayne Johnson's Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle sequel drops first teaser as US release date is confirmed|publisher=''Digital Spy''|date=April 24, 2018|first=Justin|last=Harp}}</ref> According to Kevin Hart, the sequel will have the main four stars, Dwayne Johnson, Karen Gillan, Jack Black, Nick Jonas, and himself, back. The cast and crew will start shooting for the sequel by the end of January 2019.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jumanji sequel confirmed by Kevin Hart and run, it's a stampede |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/10/03/jumanji-sequel-confirmed-by-kevin-hart-and-run-its-a-stampede-8000588/ |website=Metro |publisher=Mel Evans |accessdate=17 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181004131905/https://metro.co.uk/2018/10/03/jumanji-sequel-confirmed-by-kevin-hart-and-run-its-a-stampede-8000588/ |archive-date=2018-10-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>

{{Infobox company |name = Klei Entertainment Inc. |logo = Klei Entertainment logo new.png |type = [[Privately held company|Private]] |foundation = {{start date and age|2005|07}} |location = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] |key_people = Jamie Cheng
Jeffrey Agala |industry = [[Video game industry]] |products = ''[[Eets]]'' series
''[[Shank (video game)|Shank]]'' series
''[[Mark of the Ninja]]''
''[[Don't Starve]]''
''[[Invisible, Inc.]]'' |num_employees = 35 |homepage = [https://klei.com/ klei.com] }} '''Klei Entertainment Inc.''' ({{IPAc-en|k|l|eɪ}} {{respell|klay|}}{{cite web |title=Klei - It rhymes with play |url=https://klei.com/ |website=Klei.com |accessdate=7 September 2018}}) is an independent [[video game developer|game development studio]] located in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. Klei was formed in July 2005 by Jamie Cheng. They are best known for ''[[Eets]]'' series, ''[[Shank (video game)|Shank]]'' series, ''[[Mark of the Ninja]]'', ''[[Don't Starve]]'', ''[[Invisible, Inc.|Invisible, Inc]].'' and ''[[Oxygen Not Included]]''. == History == Jamie Cheng and [[Alex Garden]] founded Klei Entertainment in July 2005. Prior to the formation of Klei, Cheng worked as a specialist AI [[game programmer|programmer]] at [[Relic Entertainment]], then owned by [[THQ]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=11058|title=Road To The IGF: Klei Entertainment's Eets|last=Wallis|first=Alistair|date=2006-09-29|publisher=[[Gamasutra]]|accessdate=2011-01-21}} Cheng acquired seed funding for Klei by selling his THQ shares earned at Relic and getting a $10,000 loan from his brother.{{Cite web |url=https://thecdm.ca/people/workshop-presenters/jamie-cheng |publisher=Centre for Digital Media |accessdate=2017-03-17 |title=Profile: Jamie Cheng}} Klei had 11 employees in 2009{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/25698/QA_Klei_Founder_Cheng_Discusses_Shank_Animation_Repression.php |publisher=Gamasutra |accessdate=2011-01-21 |date=2009-10-22 |title=Q&A: Klei Founder Cheng Discusses Shank, Animation, Repression |first=Chris |last=Remo}} and as of May 2013 has grown to 35 employees.{{Cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2013/5/29/4362838/the-birth-and-re-birth-of-klei |publisher=Polygon |accessdate=2017-03-15 |date=2013-05-29 |title=The Birth and Re-birth of Klei |first=Chris |last=Plante}} Their first title, ''[[Eets]]'' was first released March 27, 2006, for [[Microsoft Windows]],{{Cite web |url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/6100/ |publisher=[[Steam (software)|Steam]] |title=Eets on Steam |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202125736/http://store.steampowered.com/app/6100/ |archivedate=2011-02-02 |df= }} then for [[Mac OS X]] on December 9, 2010.{{Cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/12/09/eets-unleashed-on-mac-75-off-via-steam/ |title=Eets unleashed on Mac, 75% off via Steam |first=Randy |last=Nelson |date=2010-12-09 |accessdate=2010-12-17 |publisher=Joystiq}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.krugerheavyindustries.com/ |title=Eets: Hunger it's Emotional |publisher=Kruger Heavy Industries |accessdate=2010-12-17}} Between those two releases the game was ported to the Xbox 360 via the [[Xbox Live Arcade]] platform and released on April 25, 2007. Retitled ''Eets: Chowdown'', this version featured 120 new levels and an action minigame called ''Marsho Madness''.{{Cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/254551/another-xbla-double-pinball-and-eets |title=Another XBLA Double: Pinball and Eets |date=2007-04-23 |first=Mike |last=Fahey |publisher=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=2010-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016060919/http://kotaku.com/254551/another-xbla-double-pinball-and-eets |archivedate=2012-10-16 |df= }}{{Cite web |url=http://marketplace.xbox.com/en-US/Product/Eets-Chowdown/66acd000-77fe-1000-9115-d80258410825 |title=Eets: Chowdown - Xbox.com |publisher=[[xbox.com]] |accessdate=2010-12-17}} The company assisted with [[Slick Entertainment]]'s ''[[N+]]'', the Xbox Live Arcade port of the [[Adobe Flash]] game ''[[N (video game)|N]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://kleientertainment.com/n/legend-of-zelda-remade-in-n/ |date=2008-03-20 |title=Legend of Zelda remade in N+ |publisher=Klei Entertainment |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124221355/http://kleientertainment.com/n/legend-of-zelda-remade-in-n/ |archivedate=2010-11-24 |df= }} In 2008 Klei developed ''[[Sugar Rush (video game)|Sugar Rush]]'', a casual [[massively multiplayer online game]].{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/5018568/nexons-sugar-rush-arena-in-closed-beta |title=Nexon's Sugar Rush Arena in Closed Beta |accessdate=2008-07-18 |last=Greene |first=Maggie |date=2008-06-21 |publisher=Kotaku}} They announced in late August 2010, that development had stopped and the game was canceled.{{cite web |url=http://kleientertainment.com/games/sugar-rush/|title=Sugar Rush Free-to-Play online arena combat game |publisher=Klei Entertainment |accessdate=2011-01-21}} The company's fourth original title, ''Shank'', was announced at [[Penny Arcade Expo]] 2009.{{Cite web |url=http://pax.gamespot.com/story/6216832/shank-hands-on |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907222543/http://pax.gamespot.com/story/6216832/shank-hands-on |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-09-07 |title=Shank Hands-On |last=Tong |first=Sophia |date=2009-09-04 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=2009-09-05 }} It was released on August 24, 2010, for the [[PlayStation 3]], August 25, 2010, for the [[Xbox 360]] and October 26, 2010, on for Microsoft Windows.{{Cite web |url=http://shankgame.com/news/klei-signs-with-ea-partners-for-shank/ |title=Klei signs with EA Partners for Shank |date=2010-03-04 |first=Jamie |last=Cheng |publisher=Klei Entertainment |accessdate=2010-12-07}} Klei's survival adventure game ''[[Don't Starve]]'' was released on April 23, 2013. ''Don't Starve'' was released in a 2-for-1 beta format on [[Steam (software)|Steam]], allowing players to purchase two copies of the game for the price of one. Before being officially self-published, Klei sold more than 300,000 copies of ''Don't Starve'' at $15 each. On April 21, 2016, Klei released a stand-alone multiplayer version of ''[[Don't Starve]]'' called ''Don't Starve Together'', which has regular updates and individual downloadable content.{{Cite web|url=https://www.klei.com/games/dont-starve-together|title=Don't Starve Together {{!}} Klei Entertainment|website=www.klei.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-24}} On July 2, 2013, it was announced that their next release would to be titled ''[[Invisible, Inc.]]'', a turn-based espionage game released on May 12, 2015.{{cite web|title=Invisible Inc.|url=http://www.invisibleincgame.com/|accessdate=11 July 2014}} In 2017, Klei Entertainment acquired Slick Entertainment. Slick founder Nick Waanders and Jamie Cheng previously worked together at Relic Entertainment, which established a working relationship that later allowed the companies to merge.{{Cite news|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/289725/On_its_10th_birthday_Viking_Squad_dev_Slick_joins_forces_with_Klei.php|title=On its 10th birthday, Viking Squad dev Slick joins forces with Klei|last=Wawro|first=Alex|access-date=2017-07-24|language=en}} == Games developed by Klei Entertainment == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Platform(s) ! Notes ! Ref. |- | 2006 | ''[[Eets]]'' | Mac OS X, Windows, Xbox 360 | | |- | 2008 | ''[[N+]]'' | PlayStation Portable, Xbox 360, Nintendo DS | [[Game engine|Engine]] only | |- | 2010 | ''[[Sugar Rush (video game)|Sugar Rush]]'' | – | Cancelled | |- | 2010 | ''[[Shank (video game)|Shank]]'' | Linux, Mac OS X, Windows, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 | | |- | 2012 | ''[[Shank 2]]'' | Linux, Mac OS X, Windows, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 | | |- | 2012 | ''[[Mark of the Ninja]]'' | Linux, Mac OS X, Windows, Xbox 360 | | |- | 2013 | ''[[Don't Starve]]'' | Linux, OS X, Windows, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation Vita, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, Wii U, iOS, Android | | |- | 2014 | ''[[Eets|Eets Munchies]]'' | Linux, OS X, Windows, iOS | | |- | 2015 | ''[[Invisible, Inc.]]'' | Linux, OS X, Windows, PlayStation 4, iOS | | |- | 2016 | ''[[Don't Starve Together]]'' | Linux, OS X, Windows, PlayStation 4, Xbox One | | |- | 2017 | ''[[Oxygen Not Included]]'' | Linux, macOS, Windows | | |- | 2018 | ''[[Griftlands]]'' | Windows | | |- | TBA | ''[[Hot Lava (video game)|Hot Lava]]'' | Linux, macOS, Windows | | |- |} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == *{{Official website|https://klei.com/}} [[Category:Companies based in Vancouver]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Independent video game developers]] [[Category:Video game companies of Canada]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] {{Klei Entertainment}} {{Canada-videogame-company-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Lady Chatterley's Stories | image = | caption = | runtime = 0:25 | creator = Polly Quennel | starring = [[Shauna O'Brien]] | country = {{USA}} | network = [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]
MRG Entertainment | first_aired = 2000 | last_aired = April 21, 2001 | num_episodes = 17 }} '''''Lady Chatterley's Stories''''' is an [[erotic]] [[softcore pornography|softcore]] TV show that aired on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] where it continues running in syndication to this day. ==Premise== The show featured [[Shauna O'Brien]] as Lady Constance Chatterley, a land [[real estate broker|broker]] by day and at night a sexual [[psychiatrist]] to her friends and exclusive clients inside her secluded mansion. Constance is known for her taste for the sexually exotic and the ability to take an unflinching look into the sex lives of her and her clients and friends. Each episode treats the viewer to a provocative and arousing story punctuated by highly charged erotic sequences. The series featured other notable softcore stars, including [[Gabriella Hall]], [[Kim Dawson]], [[Holly Sampson]], [[Veronica Hart]], Susan Featherly, and Shannan Leigh. The show's name appears to be derived from ''[[Lady Chatterley's Lover]]'', a controversial [[novel]] by [[D.H. Lawrence]] published in 1928. == Production == The show was the result of a long line of late-night cable TV erotic series such as ''[[Erotic Confessions]]'', ''[[Women: Stories of Passion]]'', and ''[[Beverly Hills Bordello]]'' that emerged in the middle-to-late 1990s which placed an emphasis on women-centered stories where the women were in control and could be sexually independent and become actual experts in the art and science of romance and seduction. These series also served as a virtual training ground and stable, continuous employment for many a B-actress in between their movie roles. In early 2000, Showtime joined forces with Mainline Releasing Group (more popularly known as MRG Entertainment) to create a 15-episode erotic series to run on late-night weekends.(MRG had produced a similar series, ''Bedtime Stories'', for rival cable channel [[Cinemax]].) Polly Quennel was brought in as executive producer and [[Rebecca Lord]] was brought in as director. In an effort to create a totally different lead character than the usual professional sex expert in other series, they decided to utilize the famous lead character from [[D. H. Lawrence]]'s classic novel, ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' but with a more modern 21st Century, independent, sexually liberated woman. For this series, however, Lady Chatterley would become a successful [[real estate broker]] by day, and a party girl/sex expert/faux counselor by night who would create innovative ways and means to solve her friends' sexual relationship problems....all while getting her field-playing time on her own. When it came time to cast the pivotal role of Lady Chatterley, a conflict arose between the President of Showtime Networks and the series creators who were supported by some of the lower-level executives at Showtime. Many actresses tried out for the lead role with it coming down to two: [[Chloe (actress)|Chloe Nicholle]], a middle-level [[hardcore pornography|hardcore]] adult actress better known as Chloe with limited experience and even less name recognition in the B-movie/cable TV market; and [[Shauna O'Brien]], January 1992 [[Penthouse Pet]] and a 10-year veteran of B-movies. The Showtime president favored O'Brien because of her impressive qualifications and experience. She also fit into his philosophy of the erotic cable series. The series brass and lower execs favored Nicholle because they thought that she would be more suitable for the pushing of erotic boundaries that they wanted to accomplish. The second group — in direct violation of the president's orders, and while he was away on company business — pulled off a coup-d'état by giving Nicholle the lead role and began filming, production, and promotion of the series. They were able to complete production of the first two episodes; however, this ended when the Showtime president returned from his trip and found out about their actions. Production stopped, Nicholle was fired and O'Brien hired to take over the lead role, taking over the role beginning with the third episode. ==Episode list== # "A Real Man" # "Does He Have a Brother?" # "Secrets" # "Substance of Desire" # "Fantasy" # "Satisfaction" # "The Manuscript" # "The Wager" # "One Night Stand" # "Passion" # "Switch" # "The Husband" # "A Few Moments in Time" # "Before and After" # "Mystery Lover" ==References== ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0282310}} * {{tv.com show|lady-chatterleys-stories}} {{Showtime Network programming}} {{Lady Chatterley's Lover}} [[Category:Showtime (TV network) original programs]] [[Category:2000 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2001 American television series endings]] [[Category:2000s American television series]] [[Category:American anthology television series]] [[Category:Erotic television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

page.title: List of Israeli submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film

revision.comment: /* Submissions */copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; url trimming of identifying info per[[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]] and [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|Citation Style]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Contains Hebrew text}} [[Israel]] has submitted films for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] since 1964. Despite its relatively small film-making industry, ten Israeli films have been nominated for the Foreign Language Oscar, placing it in the Top Ten most nominated countries of all time. However, no Israel film has ever won the coveted award. Since 1991, the Israeli [[Ophir Award]] winner for Best Film is automatically designated the Israeli submission for the Oscar. In 2007, ''Aviva My Love'' and ''[[Sweet Mud]]'' tied for the award, necessitating a second round of voting which resulted in the submission of ''Sweet Mud''. In 2008 ''[[The Band's Visit]]'' won the Ophir Award for Best Film but was disqualified by [[AMPAS]] for containing too much English dialogue. The runner-up ''[[Beaufort (film)|Beaufort]]'' was submitted in its place, resulting in Israel's first Oscar nomination in 23 years. The most successful Israeli director is this category is [[Moshé Mizrahi]] who received two Oscar nominations representing Israel, and whose 1977 film ''[[Madame Rosa]]'' won the Oscar, representing [[List of French submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|France]]. [[Ephraim Kishon]] represented Israel twice, and was nominated both times. [[Joseph Cedar]] and [[Savi Gavison]] have represented Israel in the competition three times each, and Cedar was nominated twice. ==Submissions== The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has invited the film industries of various countries to submit their best film for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film since 1956. The Foreign Language Film Award Committee oversees the process and reviews all the submitted films. Following this, they vote via [[secret ballot]] to determine the five nominees for the award.{{cite web|title=Rule Thirteen: Special Rules for the Foreign Language Film Award |work=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |accessdate=2013-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822101822/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/rules/86/rule13.html |archivedate=22 August 2013 |df= }} Below is a list of the films that have been submitted by Israel for review by AMPAS for the Foreign Film Oscar along with the year of the submission and the year of the respective Academy Award ceremony. In most of the Israeli submissions, the majority of the dialogue was in [[Hebrew]]. Films which notably used another language as a primary spoken language are ''The Glass Cage'' and ''[[Moments (1979 film)|Moments]]'' ([[French language|French]]), ''[[Late Marriage]]'' ([[Georgian language|Georgian]]) and ''[[Ajami (film)|Ajami]]'' (the local dialect of [[Arabic language|Arabic]]). Many others, including ''Yana's Friends'' and ''Saint Clara'', feature a heavy dose of [[Russian language|Russian]]. The missing years are those in which no film was submitted by Israel. {|class="wikitable sortable" width="98%" style="background:#ffffff;" |- ! Year
(Ceremony) !! Film title used in nomination !! Original title !! Director !! Result |- | align="center" | [[1964 in film|1964]]

[[File:AdventuresIntoDarkness0901.jpg|thumb|''Adventures Into Darkness'', a [[Golden Age of Comic Books|Golden Age comics series]] that ran for 10 issues from August 1952-1954]] This is a list of fiction and media of all kinds of media featuring [[werewolves]], lycanthropy and [[shape-shifting]].
==Literature== This section includes [[novel]]s and short stories. *[[Metamorphoses]] by [[Ovid]] features King [[Lycaon (Arcadia)]] (approx 8 A.D.) *''[[Satyricon|The Satyricon]]'' by [[Petronius]] (approx. 61 AD) *"[[Bisclavret]]" from ''[[The Lais of Marie de France|Lais]]'' by [[Marie de France]] (approx. 1175) *''[[Melion]]'' (approx. 1200) *''[[Guillaume de Palerme]]'' (approx. 1200) *''[[Völsunga saga|Saga of the Völsungs]]'' Sigmund and Sinfjötli temporarily become Werewolves (Late 13th Century) *Single line reference, [[Thomas Malory]], ''[[Le Morte d'Arthur]]'' translated ''[[Le Morte d'Arthur|Death of Arthur]]'' (1469–1470), ''"Sir Marrok the good knight that was betrayed with his wyf for she made hym seven yere a werwolf."'' *[[Peter Stumpp|The Damnable Life and Death of Stubbe Peeter]] by [[George Boren]] (1590) *[[Corvetto (fairy tale)]] (1634) *"The Wehr-Wolf : a legend of the Limousin." (1828, Tales of an Antiquary, Richard Thompson) *"The Man-Wolf" by [[Leitch Ritchie]] (1831) *"Hughes the Wer-Wolf: A Kentish Legend of the Middle Ages" by [[Sutherland Menzies]] (1838) *"The White Wolf of the Hartz Mountains" is an episode from ''[[The Phantom Ship]]'' by [[Frederick Marryat]] (1839), and features a female werewolf who inhabits the [[Harz Mountains]] in Germany. *"Le Loup-garou" (1843, Elie Berthet) *''Wagner the Wehr-Wolf'' by [[G. W. M. Reynolds]] (1848) *''[[The Wolf Leader|The Wolf-Leader]]'' (Fr: ''Le Meneur de loups''), [[Alexandre Dumas, père]] (1857) *"The Man-Wolf" (Fr: "Hugues-le-loup") by [[Erckmann-Chatrian]] (1859) is set in the [[Black Forest]] of Germany, and features a noble house afflicted by an ancestral lycanthropic curse. *"[[Lokis (novella)|Lokis]]" by [[Prosper Mérimée]] (1869) *''[[The Story of Sigurd the Volsung and the Fall of the Niblungs]] (1876) *"The White Wolf of Kostopchin" by Sir Gilbert Campbell (1889) *"A Pastoral Horror" by [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] (1890) *"The Mark of the Beast" by [[Rudyard Kipling]] (1890) *"The Eyes of the Panther" by [[Ambrose Bierce]] (1891) [[File:The Were-Wolf by Clemence Housman.jpg|thumbnail|right|''The Were-Wolf'' by Housman]] *''The Other Side: A Breton Legend'' by [[Count Eric Stanislaus Stenbock]] (1893) *''The Loup-Garou!'' collected in Danvis Folks (1894) *''The Were-Wolf'' by [[Clemence Housman]] (1896) *''[[The Greek Myths]]'' by Robert Graves features King Lycaon *"The Werwolves" (sic) by [[Honore Beaugrand|H. Beaugrand]] (1898) *''The Black Douglas'' by S.R. Crockett (1899) *''[[The Camp of the Dog]]'' by [[Algernon Blackwood]] (1908) *''[[Gabriel-Ernest]]'' and "The She-Wolf" by [[Saki]] (H. H. Munro) (1910) *''The Thing in the Woods'' by [[Margery Williams]] (1913, reprinted in 1924 under the pseudonym "Harper Williams")<ref name="sd">[[Stefan Dziemianowicz]], "The Werewolf" in ''Icons of Horror and the Supernatural'', edited by [[S.T. Joshi]].Greenwood Press 2007, {{ISBN|0313337810}} (pp. 653-668).</ref> *''The Door of the Unreal'' by [[Gerald Biss]] (1919) *''Le Loup Garou'' by Alfred Machard (1920) in French. The English translation is ''The Wolf Man'' (1925). Basis for two lost werewolf films (1923 and 1932). *"Running Wolf" by [[Algernon Blackwood]] (1921) is set in the Canadian wilderness and features a spectral native American werewolf. *"The Phantom Farmhouse" by [[Seabury Quinn]] (1923) *''[[The Werewolf of Ponkert]]'' by [[H. Warner Munn]] (1925, collected 1958) *"Wolfshead" by [[Robert E. Howard]] is a [[Novella|novelette]] first published in ''[[Weird Tales]]'' in April 1926. *''Sudenmorsian'' by [[Aino Kallas]] (1928) is a [[Finland|Finnish]] werewolf tale translated into English as ''The Wolf's Bride'' by [[Alex Matson]], 1930. It was adapted as an opera by [[Tauno Pylkkänen]]. *''The White Robe'' by [[James Branch Cabell]] (1928). *"The Master of the House" by [[Oliver Onions]] (1929)<ref name="frost">Frost, Brian J. ''The Essential Guide to Werewolf Literature'', p.242. Popular Press, 2003. {{ISBN|0879728604}}</ref> *"The Wolf of St. Bonnot" by Seabury Quinn (1930) *''The Wolf in the Garden'' by [[Alfred H. Bill]] (1931) is set in post-Revolutionary New York.<ref name="sd" /> *"Tarnhelm" by [[Hugh Walpole]] (1933) *''[[The Werewolf of Paris]]'' by [[Guy Endore]] (1933)<ref name="sd" /> *"Death of a Poacher" by [[H. Russell Wakefield]] (1935) *"The Point of Thirty Miles" by [[T. H. White]] (1935)<ref name="frost" /> *''[[The Undying Monster: a Tale of the Fifth Dimension]]'' by [[Jessie Douglas Kerruish]] (1936) *''Grey Shapes'' by Jack Mann ([[Evelyn Charles Vivian]]) (1937) *"The Hairy Ones Shall Dance" by [[Manly Wade Wellman]] (1938) *''[[Darker Than You Think]]'', a werewolf classic by [[Jack Williamson]] (1940, expanded 1948)<ref name="sd" /> *''The White Wolf'' by Franklin Gregory (1941) *''The Compleat Werewolf'' by [[Anthony Boucher]] (1942) (an anthology; only the title story involves werewolves) *"The Kill" by [[Peter Fleming (writer)|Peter Fleming]] (1942) *"The Refugee" by [[Jane Rice]] (1943)<ref name="frost" /> *"Eena" by [[Manly Banister]] (1947)<ref name="sd" /> *"[[There Shall Be No Darkness]]" by [[James Blish]] (1950)<ref name="sd" /> *''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' Volume 1: [[The Fellowship of the Ring]] (Mentioned only) (1954) *"Wolves Don't Cry" by [[Bruce Elliott (writer)|Bruce Elliott]] (1954)<ref name="sd" /> *"The Hunt" by [[Joseph Payne Brennan]] (1958) *''[[Invaders from the Dark]]'' by [[Greye La Spina]] (1960) *''[[Three Hearts and Three Lions]]'' by [[Poul Anderson]] (1961) is an [[alternate history (fiction)|alternate history]] fantasy wherein a modern day engineer is translated to a universe where the [[Matter of France]] is history. It includes an episode in which the hero must deduce which of four people in a family is the werewolf that plagued the area. *''[[Operation Chaos (novel)|Operation Chaos]]'' by [[Poul Anderson]] (1971) and its sequel, ''[[Operation Luna]]'', are first-person narration by the werewolf hero in a fantasy alternate history United States where magic and technology combine. Werewolfery is not only hereditary, but a recessive gene, and the polarized component of moonlight has been isolated, so that the hero can use a ''Were-flash'' to transform without the full moon. *"Reflections for the Winter of My Soul" by [[Karl Edward Wagner]] (1973) *"Lila the Werewolf" by [[Peter S. Beagle]] (1974) *"The Hero as Werwolf" by [[Gene Wolfe]] (1975) *''Lisa Kane'' by [[Richard A. Lupoff]] (1976) *''[[The Silmarillion]]'' by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] (1977) *''[[The WolfMan (1977 book)|The WolfMan]]'' by Carl Dreadstone (1977) *''[[The Werewolf of London]]'' by Carl Dreadstone (1977) *''[[The Howling]]'' (1977) by [[Gary Brandner]] and its sequels *''The Wolfen'' by [[Whitley Strieber]] (1978) portrays werewolves as predators of humanity, acting as a "natural" control on their population now that it has been removed from the traditional limits of nature. The concept was reused, with some changes, as a historic practice long since abandoned in the now classic White Wolf tabletop RPG, ''[[Werewolf: The Apocalypse]]''. *''The Nightwalker'' by [[Thomas Tessier]] (1979) features a deranged Vietnam Vet resident in London who transforms into a werewolf.<ref>[[Douglas E. Winter]], "Writers of Today" in Sullivan</ref> *''Moondeath'' by [[Rick Hautala]] *"The Company of Wolves", "The Werewolf" and "Wolf-Alice", collected in the book ''[[The Bloody Chamber]]'' (1979) by [[Angela Carter]], are modern takes on the story of [[Little Red Riding Hood]] in which the wolf is actually a werewolf. These stories inspired the film ''[[The Company of Wolves]]'' (1984). *''[[Tales of the Werewolf Clan: Volume One|Tales of the Werewolf Clan, Volume 1, In the Tomb of the Bishop]]'' by [[H. Warner Munn]] (1979) **''[[Tales of the Werewolf Clan: Volume Two|Tales of the Werewolf Clan, Volume 2, The Master Goes Home]]'' (1980) *"The Book of the Beast" trilogy: ''The Orphan'' (1980), ''The Captive'' (1981), ''The Beast'' by Robert Stallman (1982) *''[[The Beast Within (novel) | The Beast Within]]'' (1981) by [[Edward Levy]] *''Blood Fever'' (1982) by [[Kit Reed]] *The ''[[Discworld]]'' (1983–) series by [[Terry Pratchett]] features a number of werewolves in supporting roles, most notably [[Captain Angua von Überwald|Angua]] of the [[Ankh-Morpork]] [[Ankh-Morpork City Watch|Night Watch]]. These werewolves can be both born and infected by a bite. *''[[The Talisman (King & Straub novel)|The Talisman]]'' (1983), co-written by Stephen King and Peter Straub, features werewolves, known simply as Wolfs, who inhabit the far western parts of a world parallel to America called the Territories and serve as royal herdsman or bodyguards. *''The Godforsaken'' by [[Chelsea Quinn Yarbro]] (1983) *''[[The Wolf's Hour]]'' by [[Robert R. McCammon]] (1984) *''[[Cycle of the Werewolf]]'', an illustrated novel by [[Stephen King]] (1983) *''[[The Dark Cry of the Moon]]'' by [[Charles L. Grant]] (1986) *''Werewolves'' by [[Jane Yolen]], ed. (1988) *''[[Wolf Moon]]'' by [[Charles de Lint]] (1988) *"[[The Skin Trade]]" by [[George R.R. Martin]] (1989) *"[[The Manipulator]]" by [[Dana Brookins]] (1989) *''[[Howling Mad]]'' by [[Peter David]] (1989) features a wolf who has been bitten by a werewolf, becoming a "werehuman" as a result, providing a unique perspective on human civilization. *''Moon Dance'' (1989) by [[S.P. Somtow]] follows the immigration of a motley group of European werewolves to colonial America, where they confront disturbed human characters as well as Native American werewolves. *''Tamed'' by Douglas R. Brown involves werewolves which are sold as pets. *''The Werewolves of London'' by [[Brian Stableford]] (1990) *''WerewolveSS'' by [[Jerry Ahern]] and Sharon Ahern (1990) *''The Ultimate Werewolf'' by [[Harlan Ellison]], ed. (1991) *''[[The Wild (novel)|The Wild]]'' (1991) by [[Whitley Strieber]] portrays the werewolf as a medium through which to bring human intelligence and spirit back into nature. *''[[Animals (book)|Animals]]'' (1992) by [[John Skipp]] and [[Craig Spector]] *''Blood Trail'' by [[Tanya Huff]] (1992) is Volume 2 in Huff's vampire series. This instalment deals with a werewolf clan. *''Wild Blood'' by [[Nancy A. Collins]] (1993) *''[[Wolf Kill]]'' by [[Gregg Almquist]] *The ''[[Anita Blake: Vampire Hunter]]'' series (1993 onwards) by [[Laurell K. Hamilton]] features a number of werewolf characters and explores the concept of werewolf packs. Lycanthropy is a disease, and a major character has contracted it from a faulty vaccine against it. *''Vampire World 1: Blood Brothers'' by [[Brian Lumley]] (1992) is the first part of the [[Necroscope]] series, and features the [[Wamphyri]] werewolf Canker Canison. It was followed by: **''Vampire World 2: The Last Aerie'' (1993) **''Vampire World 3: Bloodwars'' (1994) **''[[Necroscope]]: The Lost Years Volume 1'' (1995) **''[[Necroscope]]: The Lost Years Volume 2'' (1996) *''[[Thor (novel)]]'' by Wayne Smith (1994) has a German Shepherd who protects his family from a relative who was infected by a werewolf. This was the basis for the movie ''[[Bad Moon]]''. *''[[The History of Middle-earth]] volume II The War of the Jewels'' (1994) *''Women Who Run with the Werewolves'' by [[Pam Keesey]] (1995) *''Nadya – The Wolf Chronicles'' by [[Pat Murphy (writer)|Pat Murphy]] (1996) is about a race of European werewolves who immigrate to the United States in the nineteenth century. *''The Werewolf Chronicles'' by [[Rodman Philbrick]] and Lynn Harnett (1996) *''[[Return of The Wolfman]]'' by [[Jeff Rovin]] (1998) *''[[The Silver Wolf]]'' (1998) by [[Alice Borchardt]] follows the lives of several werewolves in ancient Rome and Ireland. It was followed by: **''[[Night of the Wolf]]'' (1999) **''[[The Wolf King]]'' *''The Werewolf Book'' by [[Brad Steiger]] (1999) *''[[Blood and Chocolate (novel)|Blood and Chocolate]]'' by [[Annette Curtis Klause]] (1999) *''Touch of the Wolf'' by Susan Krinard (1999) is first in a series of historical werewolf novels. *''[[Murcheston: The Wolf's Tale]]'' by David Holland ([[2000 in literature|2000]]) *The series ''Prowlers'' (2001–2) by [[Christopher Golden]] portrays werewolves as a separate species, mostly ruthless monsters but occasionally decent individuals. *''[[Fool Moon (novel)|Fool Moon]]'' by [[Jim Butcher]], book two of [[The Dresden Files]] (2001) *''[[Summer Knight (novel)|Summer Knight]]'' by [[Jim Butcher]], book four of [[The Dresden Files]] (2003) *''[[Bitten (Armstrong novel)|Bitten]]'' by [[Kelley Armstrong]] (2001). It was followed by: **''[[Stolen (Armstrong novel)|Stolen]]'' (2002) **''[[Broken (Armstrong novel)|Broken]]'' (2006) **''[[Frostbitten (Armstrong novel)|Frostbitten]]'' (2009) *''Low Red Moon'' by [[Caitlín R. Kiernan]] (2003) contains multiple allusions to lycanthropy though no actual werewolves appear in the story. Other works by Kiernan containing werewolves or mentions of werewolves include "The Black Alphabet", "The Road of Pins", "Stoker's Mistress", and "Untitled 4". *''The Essential Guide to Werewolf Literature'' by [[Brian Frost]] (2003) *''[[World of the Lupi]]'' series by [[Eileen Wilks]] (2003–present) *''Van Helsing'' by Kevin Ryan (2004) *The ''Crimson City'' series by Liz Maverick, [[Marjorie M. Liu|Marjorie Liu]], Patti O'Shea, and Carolyn Jewel (2005–present) *''[[Kitty and the Midnight Hour]]'' by [[Carrie Vaughn]] features werewolf radio show host Kitty Norville (2005). It was followed by ''Kitty Goes to Washington'' (2006), ''Kitty Takes a Holiday'' (2007), ''Kitty and the Silver Bullet'' (2008), ''Kitty and the Dead Man's Hand'' (2009), and ''Kitty Raises Hell'' (2009). *''[[Maximum Ride]]'' series by [[James Patterson]] features genetically engineered werewolves called "Erasers" as antagonists (2005–6). *''[[The Demonata]] '' series by [[Darren Shan]] (2005–6) *''[[Frostbite (Wellington novel)|Frostbite]]'' by [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]], first published online serially, then in book format. *''Moon Called'' by [[Patricia Briggs]] (2006) is told from the viewpoint of a [[coyote]] [[Skin-walker (mythology)|skinwalker]] who was raised by a werewolf pack. This is the first of the [[Mercy Thompson series]], including: **''Blood Bound'' (2007), ''Iron Kissed'' (2008) and ''Bone Crossed''. *''[[New Moon (novel)|New Moon]]'' by [[Stephenie Meyer]] (2006) features a group of teenagers from the Native American [[Quileute]] tribe who transform into wolves. ** ''[[Eclipse (Meyer novel)|Eclipse]]'' (2007) ** ''[[Breaking Dawn]]'' (2008) ** ''[[The Short Second Life of Bree Tanner]]'' (2010) tells part of the story of the antagonist of Eclipse; has references to "howler vampires", who are in fact the Quileute wolves. *''[[The Wolf Man: Hunter's Moon]]'' by [[Michael Jan Friedman]] (2007) *''The Wolfman'' by Nicholas Pekearo (2009) *''[[The Southern Vampire Mysteries]]'' series by [[Charlaine Harris]] features a wide array of supernatural beings, including werewolves. **''[[Club Dead]]'' introduces the werewolf character of Alcide Herveaux. *''Werewolf Smackdown: A Novel'' by Mario Acevedo (2010), part of the Felix Gomez series of supernatural novels. *''[[Overwinter (novel)|Overwinter]]'' by [[David Wellington (author)|David Wellington]] (2010), sequel to ''Frostbite''. *''Jane Slayre'' by [[Charlotte Brontë]] and Sherri Browning Erwin (2010) *''[[Being Human Novels|Being Human]]'' series by [[Simon Guerrier]], [[Mark Michalowski]] and [[James Goss (producer)|James Gross]] (2010) **''[[Being Human Novels#The Road|The Road]]'' by Simon Guerrier (2010) **''[[Being Human Novels#Chasers|Chasers]]'' by Mark Michalowski (2010) **''[[Being Human Novels#Bad Blood|Bad Blood]]'' by James Gross (2010) *''Grave Expectations'' by [[Charles Dickens]] and Sherri Browning Erwin (2011) *''Saamaanthaa'' by d. t. neal (2011) *"A Death by the Sea" by Cooper Renner (2011) * "A Spurious Death in a Foreign Country" by Cooper Renner (2011) *''The Last Werewolf'' by [[Glen Duncan]] (2011) *''Nochebosque'' by [[Juan Carlos Chirinos]] (2011) *''High Moor'' by [[Graeme Reynolds]] (novel, 2012) *''The Wolf Gift'' by [[Anne Rice]] (novel, 2012) *''Changes: A Werewolf's Saga Part 1'' by Michael Lampman (novel, 2012) *''The Pack: A Werewolf's Saga Part 2'' by Michael Lampman (novel, 2012) *''Redemption: A Werewolf's Saga Part 3'' by Michael Lampman (novel, 2012) *''Wolf Hunter'' by J.L.
