[[Principal photography]] for ''Full Sequence'' began in London in June 2010 with a largely British cast.{{citation | url = http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/19903 | title = 12 Man Creature in 'The Human Centipede: Full Sequence'! | first=Brad | last=Miska | work=[[Bloody Disgusting]] | date = 20 April 2010 | accessdate = 8 May 2010}} A teaser trailer was released on 24 September, in which Six introduced Martin, a man wearing a cardboard box over his head, as the new doctor.{{citation | title = Exclusive Premiere: The Teaser Trailer for "The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)" | url = http://www.ifc.com/news/2010/09/human-centipede-2.php | work=[[IFC Films]] | author=Matt Singer | accessdate=25 September 2010}} ==Release== ===United States=== The film had its United States [[premiere]] at [[Fantastic Fest]] in [[Austin, Texas]], on 22 September 2011. The film's distributor, [[IFC Films]], gave audience members complimentary [[Airsickness bag|barf bags]] at the screening, and stationed an ambulance outside the theater as a [[gimmick]]. However, one audience member became so physically ill during the premiere that actual paramedics had to assist her. The film began a [[Limited release|limited theatrical release]] in the United States on 7 October 2011.[http://www.ifc.com/news/2011/09/human-centipede-2-full-trailer.php Singer, Matt. "Shock and ''Eww'' in ''The Human Centipede II'' Trailer." IFC.com. 27 September 2011.] Accessed 3 October 2011. It was released unrated and only had [[Midnight movie|midnight showings]]. The film was released in an "unrated [[director's cut]]" on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] on 14 February 2012;{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdactive.com/news/releases/human-centipede-ii-full-sequence.html|title=News: Human Centipede II: Full Sequence (US DVD R1 {{!}} BD RA) – DVDActive|date=4 January 2012|work=DVDActive|accessdate=13 January 2012}} the film runs a total 91 minutes. A full-color version of the film was released for the first time in the United States on 27 October 2015, exclusively on ''The Human Centipede: The Complete Sequence'' Blu-ray set.{{cite web|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3362742/the-human-centipede-the-complete-sequence-coming-to-blu-ray/|title='The Human Centipede: The Complete Sequence' Coming to Blu-ray|last=Barkan|first=Jonathan|date=23 September 2015|website=Bloody Disgusting|access-date=27 September 2015}} In April 2016, a Tennessee high school teacher was suspended after the film was played during class. Tom Six responded by tweeting "It should be mandatory to watch THC2 in school classes...It deals with a character that is bullied and what to do!" Six also said that he would be giving the teacher an autographed copy of the film.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/04/29/human-centipede-2-high-school|title=Teacher suspended for showing high school class Human Centipede 2|website=Ew.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} === Censorship === ==== United Kingdom ==== In June 2011, the [[British Board of Film Classification]] (BBFC) refused to classify ''The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence)'' for a [[direct-to-video]] release, effectively meaning that the film could not legally be supplied in any format in the UK.{{Cite web|url=http://bbfc.co.uk/about-bbfc/media-centre/bbfc-rejects-human-centipede-ii-full-sequence|title=BBFC rejects THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE II (FULL SEQUENCE) {{!}} British Board of Film Classification|website=bbfc.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}} The BBFC had given the preceding ''First Sequence'' title an [[18 (British Board of Film Classification)|18 certificate]]. The Board stated that they had considered ''First Sequence'' to be "undoubtedly tasteless and disgusting", but deemed it acceptable for release because the "centipede" was the product of a "revolting medical experiment". By contrast, the BBFC report on ''Full Sequence'' stated that the film's content was too extreme for an 18 certificate and was "sexually violent, and potentially obscene". The board members felt that the centipede of ''Full Sequence'' existed purely as "the object of the protagonist's depraved sexual fantasy". They criticised the film for making "little attempt to portray any of the victims in the film as anything other than objects to be brutalised and degraded for the amusement and sexual arousal of the main character and for the pleasure of the viewer,"{{Cite web|url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/human-centipede-2-full-sequence|title=THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE 2 (FULL SEQUENCE) {{!}} British Board of Film Classification|website=bbfc.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}} and stated their opinion that the film was potentially in breach of the [[Obscene Publications Act 1959|Obscene Publications Act]]. The BBFC initially suggested that cutting the film would not affect the decision, "as the unacceptable material featured throughout". Tom Six responded to the BBFC's decision in a statement released the next day:
Thank you BBFC for putting spoilers of my movie on your website and thank you for banning my film in this exceptional way. Apparently I made an horrific horror-film, but shouldn't a good horror film be horrific? My dear people it is a f**cking MOVIE. It is all fictional. Not real. It is all make-belief ''[[[sic]]]''. It is art. Give people their own choice to watch it or not. If people can't handle or like my movies they just don't watch them. If people like my movies they have to be able to see it any time, anywhere also in the UK.{{Cite web|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/news/human-centipede-ii-rejected-bbfc/|title=Human Centipede II Rejected By BBFC|last=O'Hara|first=Helen|date=2011-06-07|website=[[Empire Magazine|Empire]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}}
Eureka Entertainment, the film's UK distributor, issued a statement criticising the ban, echoing Six's sentiments about the revelation of plot details in the BBFC's report, and announcing their intention to appeal to the [[Video Appeals Committee]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.starburstmagazine.com/news-why-the-bbfc-dont-want-you-to-see-human-centipede-2|title=News: Why The BBFC Don't Want You To See HUMAN CENTIPEDE 2 With Response From Distributors - STARBURST Magazine|last=Heys|first=Kris|date=2011-06-07|work=STARBURST Magazine|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-GB}} In October 2011, the BBFC ultimately granted the film an [[18 (British Board of Film Classification)|18 certificate]] for "very strong bloody violence and gore, and sexual violence" after 32 compulsory cuts were made, totalling 2 minutes and 37 seconds.{{Cite web|url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/human-centipede-ii-full-sequence|title=THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE II (FULL SEQUENCE) {{!}} British Board of Film Classification|website=bbfc.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}} [[Quentin Thomas|Sir Quentin Thomas]], president of the BBFC, stated:
When we first examined this work earlier this year we judged that, as submitted, it was unsuitable for classification; and, as we explained to the company, we could not ourselves see how cuts could produce a viable and classifiable work. That remains the view of one of our Vice Presidents, Gerard Lemos, who is therefore abstaining from the Board's collective decision. The company lodged an appeal against our decision to refuse classification. In the course of preparations for that appeal, the company proposed a number of cuts which it was right for us to consider. In response, after further examination, we proposed a more extensive series of cuts. These cuts produce a work which many will find difficult but which I believe can properly be classified at the adult level. The company has now accepted these cuts, withdrawn its appeal and the work has been classified, as cut, at 18.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbfc.co.uk/about-bbfc/media-centre/bbfc-has-awarded-18-classification-cut-version-human-centipede-ii|title=The British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) has awarded an '18' classification to a cut version of THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE II (FULL SEQUENCE), following 32 cuts. {{!}} British Board of Film Classification|website=www.bbfc.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}
The sales director of Eureka Entertainment supported the decision, stating:
We are really pleased that after nearly four months of detailed discussion and debate, we have been able to reach an agreement with the BBFC and to produce a very viable cut of the film which will both excite and challenge its fans. Naturally we have a slight disappointment that we have had to make cuts, but we feel that the storyline has not been compromised and the level of horror has been sustained.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/oct/06/human-centipede-2-18-classification|title=Human Centipede 2 wins certificate 18 classification from British censors|last=Shoard|first=Catherine|date=2011-10-06|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}}
====Australia and New Zealand==== In May 2011, the uncut film was originally granted an [[Motion picture rating system#Australia|R18+]] classification by the [[Australian Classification Board]] (ACB). However, this decision was later overruled after Minister for Justice [[Brendan O'Connor (politician)|Brendan O'Connor]] asked for a review of the rating by the [[Australian Classification Review Board]]. On 28 November 2011, the film was reviewed and by unanimous decision of a three-person board, refused classification.{{cite press release |title=The Human Centipede II (full sequence) classified RC upon review |publisher=Classification Review Board |date=28 November 2011 |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/%289A5D88DBA63D32A661E6369859739356%29~CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf/$file/CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf |format=pdf |accessdate=11 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215232003/http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(9A5D88DBA63D32A661E6369859739356)~CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf/$file/CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf |archivedate=15 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Several groups and individuals, including [[FamilyVoice Australia]],{{Cite web|url=https://christiantoday.com.au/news/human-centipede-movie-ban-welcomed-by-pro-family-organisation.html|title=Human Centipede movie ban welcomed by pro-family organisation|website=christiantoday.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}} Collective Shout{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/a-centipede-banned-by-special-request-20111209-1onpg.html|title=A centipede banned, by special request|date=2011-12-09|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}} and [[George Pell|Cardinal George Pell]], the [[Catholic Bishops and Archbishops of Sydney|Archbishop of Sydney]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.sydneycatholic.org/people/archbishop/stc/2011//20111211_137.shtml|title=Sensible Decision|last=Pell|first=George|authorlink=Cardinal George Pell|date=2012-11-01|website=www.sydneycatholic.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101120309/http://www.sydneycatholic.org/people/archbishop/stc/2011//20111211_137.shtml|archive-date=2012-11-01|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}} welcomed the decision. Monster Pictures, the Australian distributor of the film, criticised the decision and announced their intention to re-edit and re-submit the film for review.{{Cite web|url=http://monsterpictures.com.au/blog/2011/12/01/press-release-thc2-banned/|title=PRESS RELEASE: THC2 BANNED!|last=|first=|date=2011-12-05|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111205020916/http://monsterpictures.com.au:80/blog/2011/12/01/press-release-thc2-banned/|archive-date=2011-12-05|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}} On 13 December 2011, the ACB classified a modified version of the film at R18+ for "high impact themes, violence and sexual violence".{{Cite web|url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Pages/View.aspx?sid=KFQ47H6qP09ljVU0PbElVA%253d%253d&ncdctx=vvtTWKUX7U5Zhy%252fu7ad03qbu+exvKd1sJL2Yn4EZmeCW0Cu1iBJsbbsQsfDx1LfXtxLrEWlQceXYBwhYzJ4B1Q%253d%253d|title=THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE II (FULL SEQUENCE) {{!}} Australian Classification|last=|first=|date=|website=www.classification.gov.au|language=en-au|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-28}} Monster Pictures expressed their "delight", and clarified that thirty seconds of the film had been "modified".{{Cite news|url=https://screenanarchy.com/2011/12/the-human-centipede-2-full-sequence-delightfully-disgusts-australian-cinemagoers-again.html|title=THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE 2 FULL SEQUENCE delightfully disgusts Australian cinemagoers again!|last=Bellette|first=Kwenton|date=2011-12-14|work=ScreenAnarchy|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-US}} They concluded that "this decision highlights the absurdity of Classification Review Board's decision to ban the film in the first place." Due to the reaction by Australian film authorities, the film was not submitted for theatrical distribution in New Zealand.{{cite news| url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=10770146 | work=The New Zealand Herald | first=Chris | last=Schulz | title='Gratuitous' Human Centipede 2 won't screen here | date=1 December 2011}} However, in April 2012, the DVD version was classified as "objectionable" (banned) by the [[Office of Film and Literature Classification (New Zealand)|New Zealand Office of Film & Literature Classification]].{{cite web|title=The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)|url=http://www.classificationoffice.govt.nz/DDA/Pages/Screens/DDA/WarningPage.aspx|website=NZ Register of Classification Decisions|publisher=NZ Office of Film & Literature Classification. Publication Number 1200206.000|accessdate=26 March 2017}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence)'' opened at 45th place with $49,456, for an average of $2,748, in the 18 theaters where it premiered. With four theaters added the next weekend, the film dropped a modest 29.9% with $34,679. Its third weekend saw a 56.2% drop despite having two more theaters added. However, in its fourth weekend, the film lost 12 theaters, causing a 61.9% drop ($5,792). In its final weekend, it grossed $2,267, putting the movie's resting spot at #95 for the weekend.{{cite news|last=Musetto|first=V A|title=Inhuman attachment|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=humancentipede2.htm|work=Box Office Mojo|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=12 October 2011|date=18 October 2012}} The film grossed $5,824 in [[Iceland]] and $1,511 in the United Kingdom. Released in [[Peru]] in April 2012, the horror picture grossed $21,111 there. At the end of its run, the film made $141,877, about half of what the previous installment had grossed. ===Critical response=== The film has a rating of 30% at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 77 reviews, with a consensus that reads "''The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)'' attempts to weave in social commentary but as the movie wears on, it loses its ability to repulse and shock and ends up obnoxious and annoying."{{rotten-tomatoes|the_human_centipede_ii|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} Accessed 20 April 2014. At [[Metacritic]], it rates 17 out of 100, indicating "overwhelming dislike", based on 22 reviews.{{metacritic film|the-human-centipede-ii-full-sequence|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} Giving it a score of 7 out of 10, ''[[Bloody Disgusting]]'' writer Brad Miska said the film was a "brilliant response to critics of his first film. It makes a strong statement that it's just a movie and that people take his work way too seriously, while also implementing a unique concept". Miska added that he "found it an intensely engaging and absolutely hilarious meta experience that gets its point across with flying colors", but was critical of the script's lack of depth.{{cite web|last=Miska|first=Brad|title=Review: The Human Centipede Part 2 (Full Sequence) (limited)|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/film/4823/review|work=[[Bloody Disgusting]]|publisher=The Collective|accessdate=12 October 2011}} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer Owen Gleiberman gave the film a B+ rating, stating that viewers "may feel gripped by the horror of what you're seeing and the terror of what's coming". Gleiberman noted how "The scatological climax would have the Marquis de Sade gagging into his popcorn."{{cite news|last=Gleiberman|first=Owen|title=Movie Review: The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20534454,00.html|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=[[Time Warner]]|accessdate=12 October 2011|date=12 October 2011}} Writing in the ''[[New York Post]]'', V. A. Musetto gave the film 3 out of 4 and said ''Full Sequence'' "is sick, disgusting and vile. (but) It's also demonically funny, stylish and ingenious."{{cite news|last=Musetto|first=V A|title=Inhuman attachment|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/inhuman_attachment_X6W2IGCw3GrikUB13I23xN?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME=|work=New York Post|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=12 October 2011|date=7 October 2011}} Jen Yamato, writing for ''Movieline'', criticized the film's excessive gore and the way director Tom Six seemed to dislike his own audience, specifying "It's not really a film one can or should 'enjoy', which is what Six seems to be telling his own audience, the fans who giggled through ''The Human Centipede'' and demanded more! Gorier! More extreme! Well, those people will get what they asked for." Eric Kohn, writing for ''indieWire'', criticized the excessive grotesqueness of the film as well as Six's vanity. He stated, "Well, what if it turns someone's own body against them—is that a measure of success? To some degree, yes; it's designed to turn the tables on its own gore-hungry fans by depicting a fictionalized version of one of their own so revolting they think twice about their twisted tendencies. But it's so indulgently perverse, and so viscerally disturbing to watch—not to mention a painfully vain exercise in self-worship—that the lesson is incredibly hard-won. Take a word of warning, if you're on the fence; you don't have to see ''The Human Centipede II'' to know you don't want to see it." Some reviewers found the extreme nature of the film boring. Robert Koehler, writing for ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', found the gore so excessive that he termed it a form of lazy filmmaking. "More boring than stomach-churning, the film nevertheless contains scattered scenes and sequences so far beyond the tolerance of the squeamish that it can't be overstated; one, detailing the violent birth and death of a baby, is here simply to shock the most jaded of the jaded," he wrote. Reviewer Robert Saucedo of InsidePulse.com was more generous toward the film, but found its execution lacking. He wrote, "The film ... has a hint of intelligence hiding behind its beady little eyes. Smeared with blood and poo as it may be, this intelligence exposes a film that has something to say. The problem, unfortunately, is that director Tom Six is like a child – attempting to make a profound statement but unable to get it out eloquently or even in anything not resembling a whimper or a groan most of the time ... Who would have guessed? ''Human Centipede II'' is a treatise about horror fandom as delivered by a giggling, poop-infatuated toddler." Mark Olsen, film critic for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', expressed concern over the film's conclusion as well as its basic premise. The conclusion (which he admits is open to interpretation; did Lomax commit these crimes or not?) leaves the audience either believing that the film is a "cop-out repudiation of everything that has come prior" or that even more graphic torture is coming in the third film.[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-human-centipede-20111007-1,0,5524602.story Olsen, Mark. "Movie Review: ''The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)''." ''Los Angeles Times.'' 7 October 2011.] Accessed 7 October 2011. Regardless, Olsen concluded that writer-director Six has left himself with no good option for the third film. [[Roger Ebert]], of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', who did not assign a star rating to the original, gave this film zero stars on review, calling it "reprehensible, dismaying, ugly, artless and an affront to any notion, however remote, of human decency."[http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20111007/REVIEWS/111009982 Ebert, Roger. "Movie Review: ''The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)''." ''Chicago Sun-Times.'' 7 October 2011.] Retrieved 29 January 2012, He would later name it the worst movie of 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebertpresents.com/episodes/episode-224/videos/370|title=Roger, Christy, and Ignatiy's worst movies of the year|publisher=Ebert Presents|date=30 December 2011|accessdate=27 June 2012}} In the UK, the reception of the film was just as hostile. Chris Tookey of the [[Daily Mail]] compared director Tom Six to recently convicted Dutch murderer [[Vincent Tabak]] to argue that such films would lead to the decline of society in a strong criticism of the [[BBFC]]: "That such obviously depraved, exploitative vileness has not been banned, but has instead been granted an 18 certificate, is yet more proof that the BBFC has lost its collective marbles". {{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2055937/|title=It's not just the internet that's full of violent porn - so are cinemas |publisher=Mail Online|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=13 November 2018}} Scott Weinberg{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2011/sep/27/human-centipede-2-censors |title="Human Centipede 2": the censors saved you from a shockingly boring film |publisher=The Guardian |date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2018}} and Catherine Shoard{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/oct/06/human-centipede-2-18-classification |title="Human Centipede 2" wins certificate 18 classification from British censors |publisher=The Guardian |date=6 October 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2018}} in [[The Guardian]] and [[Mark Kermode]]{{cite news |last=Kermode |first=Mark |date=2011-11-20 |title=“Is it the end of life in the fast lane?: The all-conquering Pixar franchise stalls this time with the pedestrian Cars 2” |work=The Observer}} in [[The Observer]] praised the BBFC for heavily censoring the film, their only regret being that the BBFC could not make ''The Human Centipede 2'' into a "better" film.Smith, Martin Ian (13 January 2015). [http://filmint.nu/?p=14309 "Revulsion and Derision: Antichrist, The Human Centipede II and the British Press"]. ''[[Film International]]''. Retrieved on 13 November 2018. ===Accolades=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" border="2" cellpadding="4" background: #f9f9f9; |- align="center" ! colspan=4 style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Awards |- align="center" ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" | Award ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" | Category ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" | Recipient(s) ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" | Outcome |- |rowspan="2"|Fangoria Chainsaw Awards 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/index.php/moviestv/fearful-features/6638-the-2012-fangoria-chainsaw-awards-ballot|title=2012 Fangoria Chainsaw Awards|website=Fangoria.com|accessdate=20 January 2018}} |Worst Film |''The Human Centipede 2: Full Sequence'' |{{won}} |- |Best Limited-Release/Direct-to-DVD Film |''The Human Centipede 2: Full Sequence'' |{{nom}} |- |} ==Sequel== {{main|The Human Centipede 3 (Final Sequence)}} Six stated that the third film would again be very different from the previous entry, but would also start with its ending, making the trilogy similar to a centipede. In the end, the parts of the trilogy form one continuous film about four and a half hours long. He also stated that the third film would answer some "lasting questions", have a strange happy ending, and is the last of the series, as he does not want to make any more ''Centipede'' films. In an interview with DreadCentral.com, Six said the third film would "make the last one look like a Disney film. We're going to shoot the third film entirely in America, and it's going to be my favorite... It's going to upset a lot of people." Around late 2012, actor [[Dieter Laser]] and Six ended their legal battle about creative differences, which had been ongoing since March 2012. Laser and Harvey returned for the third film, which is set in the United States, and played new characters. Six had said that the film would star a "big American celebrity," have "a storyline that nobody would expect," and feature a centipede consisting of 500+ people.{{cite web |last=Rigney |first=Todd |url=http://www.beyondhollywood.com/human-centipede-3-debuts-new-poster-at-the-american-film-market/ |title=Human Centipede 3 Debuts New Poster at the American Film Market |publisher=BeyondHollywood.com |date=2013-11-07 |accessdate=2013-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208183205/http://www.beyondhollywood.com/human-centipede-3-debuts-new-poster-at-the-american-film-market/ |archivedate=8 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Filming commenced in May 2013, with [[Eric Roberts]] added to the cast. Other cast members include former pornographic actress [[Bree Olson]], [[Robert LaSardo]], and [[Tommy Lister, Jr.|Tommy "Tiny" Lister, Jr.]]. Filming concluded in June, with the film taking place in a prison. The official tagline for the film is "100% Politically Incorrect."Dread Central, 29 May 2013, "[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/67155/eric-roberts-tiny-lister-and-bree-olson-added-human-centipede-3-final-sequence Eric Roberts, Tiny Lister, and Bree Olson Added to The Human Centipede 3: Final Sequence]". Accessed 22 July 2014. ''The Human Centipede 3 (Final Sequence)'' was released both theatrically and on video on demand on 22 May 2015. ==See also== * [[List of banned films]] * [[List of black-and-white films produced since 1970]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1530509|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} * {{mojo title|humancentipede2|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|the_human_centipede_ii|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} * {{metacritic film|the-human-centipede-ii-full-sequence|The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)}} {{The Human Centipede}} {{Portal bar|Film|Horror fiction}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence), The}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2011 horror films]] [[Category:2010s independent films]] [[Category:2010s sequel films]] [[Category:Body horror films]] [[Category:Dutch films]] [[Category:Dutch drama films]] [[Category:Dutch horror films]] [[Category:Dutch independent films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Dutch black-and-white films]] [[Category:Films about abduction]] [[Category:Films about murderers]] [[Category:Films directed by Tom Six]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Films shot in London]] [[Category:Found footage films]] [[Category:Metafictional works]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in film]] [[Category:Splatter films]] [[Category:Films about rape]] [[Category:Sequel films]]

page.title: The Russell Brand Show prank telephone calls row

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Russell Brand Show'' prank telephone calls row}} {| class="wikitable" style="float:right;margin-left:1em;text-align:center;" |- | style="width:33%;"| [[Image:Russell Brand Arthur Premier.jpg|110px]] | style="width:33%;"| [[Image:JonathanRoss.jpg|110px]] | style="width:33%;"| [[Image:Andrew sachs.jpg|100px]] |- ! <small>[[Russell Brand]]</small> ! <small>[[Jonathan Ross]]</small> ! <small>[[Andrew Sachs]]</small> |} In an episode of [[BBC Radio 2|BBC Radio 2's]] [[The Russell Brand Show (radio show)|''The Russell Brand Show'']] broadcast on Saturday 18 October 2008, comedian [[Russell Brand]] and presenter [[Jonathan Ross]] made [[prank call]]s to actor [[Andrew Sachs]] that led to controversy in the United Kingdom. Brand and Ross called Sachs to interview him on-air; when he did not answer, they left a series of lewd messages on his answering machine, including comments about Brand's relationship with Sachs' granddaughter, Georgina Baillie. After initially receiving little attention, a 26 October article in ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' led to widespread criticism of Brand, Ross and the editorial decisions of the [[BBC]], with the event becoming known as "Sachsgate" or "Manuelgate" (a reference to Sachs' [[Manuel (Fawlty Towers)|character]] in ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'').<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/sachsgate-obscene-prank-calls-russell-9376380|title=Andrew Sachs was 'haunted' by obscene calls from Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross|last=Rutter|first=Claire|date=2016-12-02|work=mirror|access-date=2017-08-12}}</ref>
Brand and Ross were criticised by a number of [[Members of Parliament]], including [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]], and the BBC received a record number of complaints. The BBC suspended Ross while it and [[Ofcom]] launched investigations. Both Brand and Radio 2 controller [[Lesley Douglas]] resigned from the BBC. On 30 October, the BBC suspended Ross without pay for 12 weeks. The BBC was fined £150,000 by Ofcom.<ref>{{cite news|last=Holmwood|first=Leigh|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/apr/03/russell-brand-jonathan-ross-bbc-fine|title=BBC fined £150,000 over Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross phone prank scandal|work=The Guardian|accessdate=3 April 2009|location=London, UK}}</ref>
==Background== From April 2006 through to October 2008, [[Russell Brand]] presented the weekly BBC radio show [[The Russell Brand Show (radio show)|''The Russell Brand Show'']]. In most episodes Brand was joined by his co-host [[Matt Morgan (comedian)|Matt Morgan]] who would often steer him in certain directions regarding what to talk about. Brand sometimes called in a variety of his celebrity friends as well, including [[Noel Gallagher]], [[Alan Carr]] and [[Jonathan Ross]], to talk on the show each week.
On 11 October 2008, [[David Baddiel]] co-hosted Brand's show. Baddiel recalled having met Georgina Baillie at Brand's home and being told that her grandfather was actor [[Andrew Sachs]]. According to Baddiel, Baillie said "Don't tell him I was here!"<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC apologises for lewd phone calls by Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross|date=28 October 2008|work=[[The Times]]|author=Patrick Foster|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5022840.ece | location=London}}</ref>
==Prank calls==
On Thursday 16 October 2008, Sachs, who famously portrayed [[Manuel (Fawlty Towers)|Manuel]] in television comedy ''[[Fawlty Towers]]'', was scheduled to be a phone-in guest on Brand's evening radio show. The show was to be pre-recorded due to Brand's work commitments.<ref name="bbcApology"/>
After being unable to reach Sachs on his home telephone, Brand and his co-host of the week, fellow Radio 2 DJ [[Jonathan Ross]], left Sachs four voice messages. In the first message, Brand joked about ''Fawlty Towers'' and the fact that both he and Sachs had appeared in ''[[The Bill]]'', but was interrupted by Ross shouting out "he fucked your granddaughter". The rest of the message and the following three messages were all characterised by Brand and Ross attempting to apologise for Ross' outburst, but each quickly descended into farce, with, for example, Brand singing to Sachs: "It was consensual and she wasn't menstrual" and Ross asking to marry him.<ref name="bbcApology"/> Brand later said that listening to those calls is like hearing 'two idiots dancing towards a canyon.'<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4289499/Russell-Brand-jokes-about-Andrew-Sachs-scandal-in-new-comedy-gig.html |title=Russell Brand jokes about Andrew Sachs scandal in new comedy gig |work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London |first=Aislinn |last=Simpson |date=19 January 2009}}</ref>
==Complaints== On 25 October, Brand presented his last edition of his radio show with co-host [[Simon Amstell]], which they performed live. Shortly before going on air, Brand was informed that ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' would be running a story about the phone calls. During the show, Brand apologised to Sachs, but also devoted much of the show to deriding the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' for its support of [[Nazism]] in the run up to [[World War II]]. Even in his apology to Sachs, Brand stated "what's worse – leaving a swearword on [[Andrew Sachs]]' answerphone or tacitly supporting [[Adolf Hitler]] when he took charge of the [[Third Reich]]?"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/oct/27/russell-brand-daily-mail-fawlty-towers |title=Russell Brand highlights Mail Hitler links in apology to Fawlty Towers star |date=27 October 2008 |work=The Guardian |location=London |first=John |last=Plunkett}}</ref>
The incident escalated into a media and political storm that, in much of the British media, eclipsed news of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|global financial crisis]], the [[United States presidential election, 2008|US Presidential election]], and [[2008 Nord-Kivu fighting|fighting in the Democratic Republic of the Congo]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC suspends top stars in media storm|date=29 October 2008|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|url=http://currentaffairs.ninemsn.com.au./article.aspx?id=657414}}</ref>
Sachs later stated he had not given permission for the messages to be broadcast.<ref name="Telegraph29Oct08">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/3278635/Jonathan-Ross-and-Russell-Brand-suspended-by-BBC-over-Andrew-Sachs-calls.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|title=Jonathan Ross and Russell Brand suspended by BBC over Andrew Sachs calls|date=29 October 2008|accessdate=29 October 2008|author=Anita Singh | location=London}}</ref> The BBC originally stated that they were "not aware of any complaint by Mr Sachs", but later confirmed a complaint had been received, and apologised.<ref name="bbcApology">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7692911.stm|title=BBC apologises over Brand prank|date=27 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=27 October 2008}}</ref> Brand issued an apology for making the calls<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7691641.stm|title=Brand 'sorry' for telephone stunt|publisher=BBC|date=26 October 2008}}</ref> but stated it was "funny" during his last radio show, before the ''Mail'' had printed the story.<ref name="bbcApology" /> [[Ofcom]], the telecommunications regulator, announced its own investigation.<ref>{{cite news|author=Rob Shepherd|title= Pressure mounts over Ross and Brand phone prank|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2008/10/pressure_mounts_over_ross_and_brand_phone_prank.html|work= [[Broadcast Now]]|date=28 October 2008|accessdate=28 October 2008}}</ref> On 28 October 2008, the BBC said that it had received 4,700 complaints,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7694921.stm|title=Ofcom to launch BBC Brand inquiry|date=28 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 October 2008}}</ref> after the calls became international news.<ref name="NME29Oct08">{{cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/the-killers/40721|title=Killers and Glasvegas caught-up in Jonathan Ross and Russell Brand's BBC ban|date=29 October 2008|work=[[NME]]|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref><ref name=Times2 /> Later the same day, this number had passed 10,000.<ref name="timeline">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7694989.stm|title=Timeline: Russell Brand prank calls|publisher=BBC|date=30 October 2008}}</ref> The same afternoon, [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] called the incident "clearly inappropriate and unacceptable".<ref name="sack">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7696714.stm|title=BBC pressured to sack presenters|date=29 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> The following day the number of complaints was said to have topped 18,000.<ref name="timeline"/>
This incident resulted in the second-highest number of complaints to the BBC in recent years, second only to its airing of ''[[Jerry Springer: The Opera]]''.<ref name=Times2>{{cite news|title=Tories demand Commons debate on BBC 'Manuelgate'|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=30 October 2008|author=Philippe Naughton|url=http://timesonline.co.uk./tol/news/uk/article5047594.ece|publisher=News International Limited}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Offence record: The most complained-about shows|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 October 2008|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/29/russell-brand-jonathan-ross-complaints|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=This could spell the end for the comedy of cruelty|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://telegraph.co.uk./opinion/main.jhtml?xml=/opinion/2008/10/30/dl3001.xml}}</ref>
In reaction to the telephone calls, Baillie said that her relationship with Brand had been brief and she now felt betrayed that he had revealed it to her grandfather. Baillie called for both Brand and Ross to be sacked by the BBC and stated that she and her family would be considering whether to make a formal complaint to the police.<ref name="Telegraph29Oct08"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Jemima Kiss|date=29 October 2008|title=Sachs' granddaughter calls for Brand and Ross to be sacked|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/oct/29/russell-brand-jonathan-ross1|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London}}</ref> Sachs stated that he had no intention of making a complaint to the police or taking the matter further.<ref name="Apology accepted">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7697988.stm |title=Sachs accepts presenters' apologies|publisher=BBC|date=29 October 2008|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
===Actions taken by Ross, Brand, and the BBC=== On 29 October 2008, [[Director-General of the BBC]] [[Mark Thompson (media executive)|Mark Thompson]] announced that [[Russell Brand]] and [[Jonathan Ross]] were suspended, pending the report of an investigation by [[Tim Davie]], director of BBC audio and music.<ref name="suspended">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7696714.stm|title=Brand and Ross suspended by BBC|date=29 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BBC suspends Ross and Brand|author=Salamander Davoudi|date=29 October 2008|work=[[Financial Times]]|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c425fb84-a5b6-11dd-9d26-000077b07658.html}}</ref> The suspension meant that, for the week, Ross would not be appearing on his regular ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' television show, [[Film... (TV programme)|''Film 2008 with Jonathan Ross'']], or his Saturday-morning [[BBC Radio 2|Radio 2]] show. Similarly Brand would not be hosting his regular Saturday-night Radio 2 show or appearing as a guest captain on an episode of ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' due to be aired on 30 October; the episode had been taped before his resignation, and aired on BBC Two on 19 January 2011, more than 2 years after the incident.<ref name="Telegraph29Oct08"/> Thompson called the events a "gross lapse of taste by the performers and the production team" (who chose to broadcast the advance-recorded show) that angered [[Television licensing in the United Kingdom|licence-payers]]. Thompson offered a personal and unreserved apology to Sachs and his family.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7697354.stm|title=Brand and Ross: BBC statement|last=Thompson|first=Mark|date=29 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 October 2008}}</ref> In an interview, Sachs revealed that he had received and accepted written apologies from Brand and Ross.<ref name="Apology accepted"/> Brand resigned from the BBC later in the day.<ref name=BBCBrandQuits>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7698417.stm|date=29 October 2008|title=Brand quits BBC over prank calls|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
On the evening of 30 October it was announced that Controller of Radio 2 [[Lesley Douglas]] had tendered her resignation, which had been accepted.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7700816.stm|title= Radio 2 boss quits over call row|date=30 October 2008|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Her resignation letter did not address the question of whether Douglas herself had approved the pre-recorded show for transmission.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lesley Douglas profile: Puppet master who shunned the public eye|author=Maggie Brown|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/30/lesleydouglas-bbc|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited}}</ref> That day, Ross was suspended without pay from all BBC shows for a period of 12 weeks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ross suspended for three months|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7700816.stm|publisher=BBC|date=30 October 2008}}</ref>
The BBC issued an apology on 8 November, stating that the telephone calls were "grossly offensive" and a "serious breach of editorial standards".<ref name=Barber>{{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5109646.ece|title=David Barber, BBC executive, quits after Brand Ross scandal|work=The Times|author=Nico Hones|date=7 November 2008|accessdate=7 November 2008 | location=London}}</ref> The corporation apologised specifically to Sachs and Baillie, and also to [[Television licence|licence fee payers]]. The evening before this formal apology, David Barber, head of specialist music and compliance at Radio 2, also resigned. Like Douglas,<ref name=Notover>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7703870.stm|title=It's not all over yet|author=Torin Douglas|publisher=BBC News|date=1 November 2008|accessdate=1 November 2008}}</ref> he had been aware of the contents of the show, and had sanctioned the segment's broadcast.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/3400839/Radio-2-executive-resigns-over-Jonathan-Ross-and-Russell-Brand-prank.html|title=Radio 2 executive resigns over Jonathan Ross and Russell Brand prank|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Anita Singh|date=7 November 2008|accessdate=7 November 2008 | location=London}}</ref>
===Reactions from politicians and the media=== Fifteen [[Member of Parliament|MP]]s signed a motion in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]], tabled by Labour MP [[Andrew MacKinlay]] and Conservative MP [[Nigel Evans]], calling for Brand and Ross to no longer be funded by the [[licence fee#United Kingdom|licence fee]] (which funds the BBC). The chairman of the House of Commons [[Select Committee (Westminster System)|select committee]] on culture, media and sport, [[John Whittingdale]], stated that an investigation by the BBC was needed, but stopped short of calling for Ross and Brand to be sacked.<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC should 'take some pain' for phone prank, says Will Wyatt|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Leigh Holmwood|date=28 October 2008|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/28/bbc-russell-brand|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited}}</ref> The chairman of the [[House of Lords]] Select Committee on Communication, [[Norman Fowler, Baron Fowler|Lord Fowler]], in a letter to The Times (see Fowler in [[#Further reading|Further reading]]) stated that there were fundamental flaws in the way that the BBC was regulated and governed, and that there was "confusion all round" because two parallel bodies, the [[BBC Trust]] and Ofcom, were investigating the incident, and it was both unclear which of them the public should complain to and which of them had precedence over the other.<ref name=Times1>{{cite news|title=Russell Brand falls on his sword and a sorry Ross is taken off the air|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|author1=Patrick Foster |author2=Philip Webster |author3=Adam Sherwin |author4=Charlene Sweeney |last-author-amp=yes |date=30 October 2008|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk./tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5042843.ece}}</ref>
Shadow [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Culture Secretary]] [[Jeremy Hunt]], speaking on the Radio 4 [[Today Programme]] on 30 October, also refused to say whether he thought Ross should be sacked, asserting that politicians should remain at "arm's length" from such decisions. In a speech at the [[London School of Economics]] the previous day he had criticised the decision by the BBC to broadcast the programme, which had been recorded 2 days prior to its transmission, saying that "[t]he BBC was quite wrong to take the decision to broadcast the offensive phone calls". He also demurred about calling for the resignations of anyone in BBC management, saying that "[i]t is wrong, in principle, for politicians to be calling for heads of individual broadcasting to be removed", and criticised the BBC for not releasing the name of the person who had given the green light for the show to be broadcast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://walesonline.co.uk./showbiz-and-lifestyle/news/2008/10/30/steve-coogan-speaks-out-about-brand-and-ross-91466-22148936/|title=Steve Coogan speaks out about Brand and Ross|date=30 October 2008|author=Robin Turner|work=[[WalesOnline]]|publisher=Media Wales Ltd}}</ref><ref name=NewStatesman1>{{cite news|title=Tory weighs into Ross/Brand row|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/uk-politics/2008/10/ross-brand-bbc-hunt-public|date=29 October 2008|author=Brittany Peats|work=[[New Statesman]]}}</ref>
Hunt was speaking to the LSE about socially responsible broadcasting, and stated "I do think the BBC is a socially responsible broadcaster, I just think we need to hear that." He argued that broadcasters were not being ambitious enough, and outlined his party's plans, should it be elected to government at the next general election, to relax regulation for those broadcasters who agreed to provide only socially responsible output. In addition to citing the Ross/Brand/Sachs affair as a "perfect example" of where such a "responsibility deal" could have operated, he also pointed to [[Channel 4]] as an example, stating that it was "not good enough" for it to produce "worthy" programmes such as [[Dispatches (TV series)|''Dispatches'']] documenting alcohol abuse in the US, whilst at the same time it was broadcasting programmes such as ''[[Hollyoaks]]'' where such abuse took up, according to his estimates, 18% of screen time. The culture spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, [[Don Foster, Baron Foster of Bath|Don Foster]], criticised this idea, stating that it threatened the very foundational principles of freedom and independence of British media, arguing that such government interference in television programming would be "a very sad day for British broadcasting", and pointing out that regulatory mechanisms already exist to deal with issues such as this.<ref name=NewStatesman1 /><ref>{{cite news|title=Tories mull responsible TV incentives|author=Ian Darby|url=http://brandrepublic.com./News/858123/Tories-mull-responsible-TV-incentives/|date=30 October 2008|publisher=Haymarket Media|work=Brand Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Responsibility contract' would threaten media freedom, say Lib Dems|author=Mark Sweney|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 October 2008|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|url=http://guardian.co.uk./politics/2008/oct/29/liberaldemocrats-television}}</ref>
On 29 October, Conservative MP [[Nadine Dorries]] had already called for the BBC to terminate the contracts of both Ross and Brand, and in the Commons [[David Hanson (politician)|David Hanson]] had criticised the comments for being inappropriate and not "in keeping with broadcasting".<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC on defensive and Ofcom steps in as 10,000 complain about Brand and Ross|author=Owen Gibson|date=29 October 2008|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/29/russell-brand-jonathan-ross-bbc}}</ref> The conservative journalist [[Charles Moore (journalist)|Charles Moore]] announced he would not pay his television licence after the BBC's failure to sack Ross,<ref>Charles Moore [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/may/11/charles-moore-fined-tv-licence "The BBC was too scared to sack Jonathan Ross, so the obscenity goes on"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 22 November 2008</ref> a decision which eventually led to Moore being fined in May 2010.<ref>James Robinson [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/may/11/charles-moore-fined-tv-licence "Charles Moore fined for Jonathan Ross-inspired TV licence boycott"], ''The Guardian'', 11 May 2010</ref>
Secretary of State for Justice [[Jack Straw]], writing in his local newspaper the ''[[Lancashire Telegraph]]'' on 30 October (see Straw in [[#Further reading|Further reading]]), became the first Cabinet Minister to call for the pair to be sacked, arguing that if both presenters had worked in [[Independent Local Radio|local radio]] "they'd have been given their [[P45 (tax)|P45]] before you could say 'Jack Robinson'."<ref name=Times1 /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blackburncitizen.co.uk/news/3801342.Sack_Jonathan_Ross__say_East_Lancashire_MPs/|date=30 October 2008|title=Sack Jonathan Ross, say East Lancashire MPs Jack Straw and Nigel Evans|work=[[The Citizen (Blackburn)|The Citizen]]|location=Blackburn|publisher=Newsquest Media Group}}</ref>
On the same day, Shadow Leader of the House of Commons, [[Theresa May]], called for a Commons debate on the BBC's handling of the affair.<ref>{{cite news|title=New exit in Russell Brand row as Jonathan Ross suspended unpaid|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk./tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5050293.ece|author1=Nico Hines |author2=Philippe Naughton |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[The Times]]|location=London|publisher=News International Limited}}</ref>
===Reaction against censures and suspensions=== In the days following the suspensions, a number of celebrities, particularly from television and radio, came out in support of Brand and Ross. Many felt that, whilst the incident was unacceptable, it was not deserving of the strong criticism it received, especially when there were other issues troubling the United Kingdom.
Rod McKenzie, the editor of BBC Radio 1 ''[[Newsbeat]]'', observed on the BBC Editors' weblog (see [[#Further reading|Further reading]]) that audience reactions to Brand's and Ross' remarks had been polarised, noting that whilst his colleagues at [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]], [[BBC Radio 5 Live|Radio 5 Live]], television, and the [[BBC World Service]] had been seeing one thing, the younger audiences of Radio 1 had been reacting quite differently, and were broadly supportive of Ross and Brand. Some were amazed at the comments of the Prime Minister, with one person observing that "[t]he financial markets are wrecked and all he can do is talk about a petty joke." Others stated that people should "calm down", "get a grip", and that the subject had been "blown out of all proportion". McKenzie also characterised the reaction from the news media as containing "anger: some genuine, some of it synthetic. Some of it comes from the BBC's usual critics." He stated that for the people who worked in the media "profile and salary-envy and [[:wikt:schadenfreude|schadenfreude]] may play a part in all this. But how many heard the original transmission and how many are responding to the newspapers' quotes or others' arguments?"<ref>{{cite news|title=Criticism of Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross driven by 'salary envy', says BBC executive|author=Nicole Martin|date=29 October 2008|url=http://telegraph.co.uk./news/newstopics/celebritynews/3280037/Criticism-of-Russell-Brand-and-Jonathan-Ross-driven-by-salary-envy-says-BBC-executive.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref>
[[Tim Shaw (presenter)|Tim Shaw]], disc jockey for [[Absolute Radio]], also supported Ross and Brand, appearing on BBC News wearing a T-shirt that read "I back Brand."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com./International/Story?id=6139816&page=2|publisher=[[ABC News]]|title=BBC Comedians' Joke Falls Flat|author=Gabrial O'Rorke|date=29 October 2008}}</ref> The television presenter [[Paul O'Grady]] stated that the comedians' behaviour was, "...well out of order". However, he also suggested that the Prime Minister should get on with more important matters than complaining about media gossip.<ref>{{cite news|title= O'Grady: 'Move on from Ross and Brand'|date=30 October 2008|author=David Balls|work=[[DigitalSpy]]|url=http://digitalspy.co.uk./showbiz/a134098/ogrady-move-on-from-ross-and-brand.html}}</ref> [[Carol McGiffin]], a presenter on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s [[Daytime television|daytime]] programme ''[[Loose Women]]'' similarly supported the pair, criticising those who complained and stating that she could not wait to download the official [[podcast]] which included the incident.<ref>{{cite episode |title=[[Loose Women]] |network=[[ITV1]] |airdate=27 October 2008 |minutes=60 }}</ref>
Then-[[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] leader and friend of [[Russell Brand]], [[Noel Gallagher]], complained that the press had "dictated the tone" of the controversy, and thought it "typical of the English in general" when "10,000 people get outraged, but only days after it has happened". Gallagher claimed to have spoken to Brand, who told Gallagher he was "going to fall on his sword".<ref>{{cite news|title=Oasis' Noel Gallagher 'outraged' at Russell Brand BBC scandal|work=[[NME]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://www.nme.com/news/oasis/40735}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC|date=30 October 2008|title=Oasis star backs radio pal Brand|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7699623.stm}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[Digital Spy]]|title=Gallagher 'outraged' by Brand resignation|author=Alex Fletcher|url=http://digitalspy.co.uk./showbiz/a134117/gallagher-outraged-by-brand-resignation.html?id=134117&id=134117|publisher=Digital Spy Limited|date=30 October 2008}}</ref>
A petition on the GoPetition web site, calling for the BBC "to turn blame on the '[[Andrew Sachs]]' incident away from [[Russell Brand]] and [[Jonathan Ross]], and instead onto whoever green lighted the show" had garnered 336 signatures by 29 October. At the same time, a similar group on Facebook had over 1,000 members.<ref>{{cite news|title=Petition supports Brand and Ross|date=29 October 2008|work=[[Web User]]|url=http://webuser.co.uk./news/news.php?id=270991}}</ref> By 30 October, the petition had risen to 4,000 signatures and the Facebook group to 15,609 members.<ref name=Conlan1>{{cite news|title=Brand-Ross Facebook supporters to protest outside Daily Mail|author=Tara Conlan|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/31/facebook-jonathan-ross|date=31 October 2008}}</ref> By 2 November, the Facebook group had over 30,000 members,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/entertainment/No-laughing-matter-as-.4652344.jp|title=Have you heard the one about the gagged comedians?|last=Horne|first=Marc|date=2 November 2008|work=The Scotsman|accessdate=2 November 2008|location=Edinburgh}}</ref> which had risen to over 43,000 members by 5 November.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dancer in Sachs prank criticises BBC response|author=Owen Gibson|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=6 November 2008|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/nov/06/bbc-ross-brand-georgina-baillie}}</ref>
On 30 October, fans of Ross and Brand protested outside of the offices of the BBC. On 31 October, fans prepared to hold a protest outside of the offices of the ''Daily Mail'' and of the BBC.<ref name=Conlan1 />
Comedian [[Jimmy Carr]] also expressed his support for Ross, saying the issue had been blown out of proportion, and blamed the media themselves for escalating it further, and that Ross was a "national treasure".<ref>{{cite news | title=Ross pulls out of Comedy Awards | date=31 October 2008 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7702309.stm | publisher =BBC News | accessdate = 31 October 2008 }}</ref>
Former celebrity publicist [[Max Clifford]] played down the apparent outrage aimed at Brand. In an interview he said "I don't think this will cause any problems for Russell Brand. He's known to be controversial and, if anything, it will make him more popular amongst his fans, who will have thought this was hilarious...They won't see anything wrong in what he did. It is a big PR success for him...He will have no problem with his career."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3288422/Russell-Brand-controversy-will-only-increase-his-popularity-experts-say.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Anita Singh|date=31 October 2008|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|title=Russell Brand controversy will only increase his popularity, experts say | location=London}}</ref>
TV critic and columnist [[Charlie Brooker]] stated on his show, ''[[Charlie Brooker's Screenwipe]]'', his worry that the controversy would lead to a [[Chilling effect (term)|chilling effect]] on comedy, and that the BBC and others would self-censor too much in future. He went on to say that the attitude displayed by the complainants and the BBC's backing down would have, in earlier times, precluded the production of much of what was at the time edgy comedy and made culture poorer for it (citing ''[[Monty Python's Flying Circus]]'', ''[[The Day Today]]'' and ''[[The Young Ones (TV series)|The Young Ones]]'' amongst others as shows that would have not been commissioned owing to their controversial content). While pouring scorn on those who had complained without seeing the programme, and attacking newspapers that attempted to stir up further controversy (in particular the ''[[Daily Mail]]''), he did not appear to defend Brand and Ross in particular, stating that the possibility of people being offended by some misjudged humour is "the price you pay for freedom of speech." In a further column in ''[[The Guardian]]'', he reiterated this point as well as saying that "people who retrospectively complain to Ofcom about material they've only read about second-hand are, in essence, a bunch of sanctimonious crybabies indulging in a wretched form of masturbation."<ref>{{cite news|title=Charlie Brooker's screen burn|date=29 November 2008|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/nov/29/charlie-brooker-screen-burn-tv | location=London | accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref><ref name="BBC website">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7698477.stm|title= Prank row: Georgina Baillie's reaction|date=29 October 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=7 November 2008}}</ref><ref name ='publicityparadox'>{{cite news|author=Matthew Taylor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/oct/30/russell-brand-ross-baillie-sachs |title=Georgina Baillie: the Satanic Slut at the centre of the Ross-Brand controversy |work=The Guardian |date= 30 October 2008|accessdate=22 August 2010 | location=London}}</ref><ref name="BroadcastFiveTV">{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2008/10/five_to_air_doc_on_russell_and_ross.html|title=Five to air doc on Russell and Ross|work=Broadcast|date=31 October 2008|accessdate =2 November 2008}}</ref><ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7710341.stm|title=Radio 2 row 'out of proportion'|publisher=BBC News|date=7 November 2008|accessdate =7 November 2008}}</ref>
===Reaction from Georgina Baillie===
====Interviews==== Reacting to the suspension of [[Russell Brand]] and [[Jonathan Ross]] on 29 October, Baillie remarked: "I'm thrilled because justice has been done...It's despicable. Calling me that in public, not only does it damage my relationship with my granddad but it could permanently damage my life as well," despite having declared apathy to the sentiment referenced in the latter sentence on her Myspace page.<ref name="BBC website"/><ref name="publicityparadox"/>
A week later, on 5 November 2008, UK television channel [[Five (TV channel)|Five]] broadcast a 1-hour documentary on the incident, titled ''Russell & Ross: What the F*** Was All That About?'' featuring an exclusive interview with Baillie.<ref name="BroadcastFiveTV"/> Baillie stated in the interview that "I think it's way out of proportion what's happened and I don't hate either of them – I don't at all", going on to say "I think they're really talented comedians and I think a world without [[Jonathan Ross]] and [[Russell Brand]] would be a very sad, dull place." She concluded by saying that Brand needed to learn about respecting women, while Ross should just think before he speaks, "I don't have any harder feeling than that."<ref name="BBC"/> Baillie also made clear that she would not object to the reinstatement of both Brand and Ross.<ref name=Barber/>
On 14 May 2009, Baillie was a guest on the BBC politics and current affairs programme ''[[This Week (BBC One TV series)|This Week]]''. She was questioned by host [[Andrew Neil]] and regular guests [[Michael Portillo]] and [[Diane Abbott]] about the Brand row within discussion of the general subject of the present day worth and genuineness of public figures saying sorry, in the wake of public apologies from members of parliament (MP's) and Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] following the events of the [[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal|MP's expenses row]]. Asked by Neil if receiving an apology from Brand and Ross had mattered to her, she said yes, as she had been "publicly offended and humiliated", and her father "had been humiliated too". When asked by Abbott if all the publicity surrounding the Brand row had helped her career, she responded "not necessarily ... one would think so, but not really." Neil further asked if the apology she received had helped, she replied yes, stating "definitely" to the follow-up comment from Neil of "better to get it than not get it?" When asked finally on the row by Neil if she thought the apologies from Brand and Ross were genuine, she replied that she thought Ross' was, but the fact that Brand had joked about the row on his later tour negated his apology.
====Songwriting==== In 2010, Baillie teamed up with singer [[Adam Ant]] (whose drummer Hayley Leggs had been a member, alongside Baillie, of [[burlesque]] troupe The Satanic Sluts) to compose the song ''Gun in Your Pocket'', about Ross, Brand and the entire affair. He intended to release the song as the lead single for his ninth album ''[[Adam Ant Is the Blueblack Hussar in Marrying the Gunner's Daughter]]'' (with a rerecording of early 1980s outtake ''Who's A Goofy Bunny Then?'' as the B-side in tribute to the recently deceased [[Malcolm McLaren]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thequietus.com/articles/04165-adam-ant-interview-oasis-lady-gaga-madonna-punk |title=Features | A Wild Nobility: An Adam Ant Exclusive By Simon Price |publisher=The Quietus |accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> ''Gun in Your Pocket'' was performed live on at least one occasion, at a [[guerilla gig]] (one of several he played around this time) at London's Troubadour Café on 2 April 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adam-ant.net/april10.html |title=April 2010 News |publisher=adam-ant.net |accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adamandtheants.org/ant-news/adam-ant-live-troubadour-last-night |title=Adam Ant Live at the Troubadour Last Night | Ant Lib Ønline | Adam & the Ants Cømmunity Øutpost | Adam Ant News & Events |publisher=Adamandtheants.org |date=6 April 2010 |accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> and was setlisted, (but not performed) at Adam's ''Pirate Metal Extravanganza'' concert at the [[Scala (club)|Scala]] on 30 April 2010, while the recording received a club play when Adam DJ'd at the Family Affair clubnight in [[Shoreditch]], London on 24 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidmantell.com/Family_Of_Noise/Adam_Ant_Live.htm |title=Adam Ant Live! (Archive of) thefamilyofnoise.com |publisher=thefamilyofnoise.com |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
The single, along with its parent album, was put on hold when Adam Ant (who has a history of [[bipolar disorder]] and was widely suspected around this time to have been undergoing a [[Bipolar disorder#Manic episodes|manic]] episode)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.holymoly.com/celebrity-news/adam-ants-comeback-all-delusion45650 |title=Adam Ant's comeback "all delusion" | Celebrity News |publisher=Holy Moly! |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=22 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712214236/http://www.holymoly.com/celebrity-news/adam-ants-comeback-all-delusion45650 |archivedate=12 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> was once again [[involuntary commitment|sectioned]] on 18 May 2010 and it remained to be seen if a medicated and stabilised Adam would wish to continue this project or not.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adamandtheants.org/ant-news/adam-ant-sectioned-under-mental-health-act |title=Adam Ant Sectioned Under Mental Health Act | Ant Lib Ønline | Adam & the Ants Cømmunity Øutpost | Adam Ant News & Events |publisher=Adamandtheants.org |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=22 August 2010}}</ref> However, interviewed by [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] on 31 December 2010 Adam Ant – by his own admission once more unmedicated and now including Baillie on backing vocals in his live band – confirmed the song as still on the album. "Georgina is a friend of mine who has really been through it. Her grandad still won't speak to her because he is so hurt."<ref>Swift, Jacqui (31 December 2010). [http://www.adamandtheants.org/ant-spotting/sun-adam-ant-dont-bother-coming-my-shows "SFTW meets Adam Ant"] ''The Sun'' p50-51</ref>
''Gun in Your Pocket'' was finally released in October 2012 as the B-side to ''Cool Zombie'', the eventual first single from the album (which finally emerged in January 2013). In addition to this song, Baillie and Adam Ant composed a second track about the Ross-Brand affair, ''Rubber Medusa'', a song focussed mainly on Brand and written from Baillie's perspective. Baillie's band, the [[Fiona Bevan#Poussez Posse|Poussez Posse]], performed this second song regularly in live support slots for Ant's UK tours during 2011–2012. Commenting on the two songs in an interview by [[John Robb (musician)|John Robb]], Baillie noted "The first one that Adam and I wrote was about an ex of mine- guess who! Which is not on the album, which is called ''Gun in Your Pocket'' ...(Subsequently) the first one Adam and I wrote together was ''Rubber Medusa'', which was about Russell, Adam came up with the title which is a quote from the [[Jubilee (1978 film)|Jubilee]] film, (Brand) does look like a rubber [[Medusa]] so I see why he said it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://louderthanwar.com/25352/|title=Georgie Girl and her Poussez Posse : interview|work=Louder Than War}}</ref>
===Support for Lesley Douglas=== A number of radio personalities employed by the BBC came out in support of [[Lesley Douglas]], after her resignation. Douglas was aware of the contents of the programme, but had not heard them before they were broadcast. She sanctioned its broadcast with a single word e-mail of "Yes" sent from her [[BlackBerry]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/nov/25/lesleydouglas-bbc | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Lesley Douglas to join Universal Music | first=John | last=Plunkett | date=25 November 2008 | accessdate=23 May 2010}}</ref> Amongst her supporters were [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]] and [[Terry Wogan]], both of whom worked for BBC Radio 2 at the time, and Dame [[Liz Forgan]], who called her one of the "outstanding broadcasters of her generation", and said that the BBC had "lost its wits". Mark Thompson said that because of her knowledge of the broadcast, she had to shoulder some of the responsibility.<ref name=Notover/>
===Subsequent appearances by Brand and Ross=== Ross had been scheduled to host the 2008 [[British Comedy Awards]] for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] during the period of his suspension from the BBC; however, on 31 October he stepped down.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ross steps down from awards show|work=[[Shropshire Star]]|url=http://shropshirestar.com./2008/10/31/bbc-suspends-jonathan-ross/|date=31 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=Tara Conlan|title=Jonathan Ross pulls out of hosting British Comedy Awards|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/31/jonathan-ross-itv|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher='Guardian News and Media Limited|date=31 October 2008}}</ref>
On 31 October, Brand left the country, saying that he had work to do in America, including TV programmes and film collaborations with [[Judd Apatow]] and [[Helen Mirren]].<ref name=Notover/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7703014.stm|title=Brand to film with Helen Mirren|publisher=BBC News|date=1 November 2008|accessdate=1 November 2008}}</ref> The second series of Brand's [[Channel 4]] television show ''[[Russell Brand's Ponderland]]'' aired as normal on the previous evening, attracting 1 million viewers, the show's largest ever audience. A further 180,000 watched the show time-shifted on the Channel 4+1 [[timeshift channel]]. The first series of ''Ponderland'', aired in October 2007, had been watched by 840,000 viewers, including those watching Channel 4+1. The channel reported that it had received 164 complaints from the public, many of these criticising the decision to broadcast the programme, rather than a reflection on the content, and the majority before the programme was transmitted; the show also attracted 212 emails and phone-calls of praise from fans and as such was the most praised programme screened on [[Channel 4]] for that month.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brand praised for Ponderland|publisher=broadcastnow.co.uk|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2008/11/brand_praised_for_ponderland.html|date=5 November 2008}}</ref><ref name=Holmwood1>{{cite news|title=TV ratings: Russell Brand's post-Sachsgate TV debut bags 1m viewers|author=Leigh Holmwood|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=31 October 2008|url=http://guardian.co.uk./media/2008/oct/31/tvratings-russell-brand}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://digitalspy.co.uk./tv/a134243/brands-ponderland-draws-1m.html|title=Brand's 'Ponderland' draws 1m|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=31 October 2008|author=Neil Wilkes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Channel 4 viewers unfazed by Brand|url=http://www.metro.co.uk./fame/article.html?Channel_4_viewers_unfazed_by_Brand&in_article_id=382486|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=31 October 2008|publisher=Associated Newspapers Limited}}</ref>
Brand similarly continued to be on the front cover of [[PETA]]'s "Vegetarian Starter Kit" booklet, despite people protesting to the organisation. PETA's director, Robbie LeBlanc, said that Brand, who had previously won PETA's Sexiest Vegetarian Celebrity contest twice, would remain on the cover "because Mr Sachs, who is also a PETA supporter, has accepted Mr Brand's apology, and that's good enough for us."<ref>{{cite news|title= Russell Brand Wins Support of PETA Over BBC Prank Scandal|author=Jason Gregory|work=[[Gigwise]]|url=http://gigwise.com./news/47193/Russell-Brand-Wins-Support-Of-PETA-Over-BBC-Prank-Scandal|date=31 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nme.com./news/russell-brand/40766|title=PETA to stand by Russell Brand despite BBC ban|work=[[NME]]|date=31 October 2008}}</ref>
Brand went on to win the British Comedy Award for Best Live Standup Performer. In his acceptance speech, Brand dedicated his award to Ross.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brand wins British Comedy Award|publisher=BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7769652.stm|date=7 December 2008|accessdate =1 January 2009}}</ref>
After being taken off the air due to Ross' suspension, ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' returned to [[BBC One]] on 23 January 2009, featuring guests [[Tom Cruise]], [[Lee Evans (comedian)|Lee Evans]] and [[Stephen Fry]]. The show was watched by 5.1 million viewers, an increase from the 3.74 million of the last show before going off air. Ross' return attracted 25 complaints and 3 messages of support to the BBC.<ref name="BBC24Jan09">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7849582.stm |title=Ross TV return is watched by 5.1m |date=24 January 2009 |accessdate=27 January 2009 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
In 2009, ''[[Friday Night with Jonathan Ross]]'' was nominated for a BAFTA. According to ''[[The Times]]'', Ross was nominated soon after he was banned.<ref>{{cite news|last=Foster|first=Patrick|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5971275.ece|title=BBC banned offensive Ross, then put him up for a Bafta|work=The Times|date=25 March 2009|accessdate=26 March 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Melody Sachs complained about Ross being nominated so soon after the controversy in an interview with ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', saying: "I am amazed that Ross should get rewarded with a mouth like his. Nobody is saying he hasn't got talent, but what he did was so disgusting. Of course he is not worth the money, but he is good at his job. However, I don't think he should be rewarded so soon after what happened. It is like people are saying, 'Let's forget all about it and see what we can give him.' It is wrong and bad timing to give or even put up this guy for recognition when he has done such a terrible thing. It was unforgivable, really. I'm not angry, I just don't believe it."<ref name="DT BAFTA">{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Anita|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/5043185/Baftas-family-of-Andrew-Sachs-flabbergasted-by-Jonathan-Ross-nomination.html|title=Baftas: family of Andrew Sachs 'flabbergasted' by Jonathan Ross nomination|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=24 March 2009|accessdate=24 March 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
Sachs himself said that the nomination was: "a bit of a surprise", and that: "One would question the reasons when it comes so quickly after what happened. I wonder how much it has to do with trying to comfort him. I don't know. That is how it happens. That is showbusiness."<ref name="DT BAFTA"/>
==BBC Trust ruling== On 21 November 2008, the BBC's watchdog [[BBC Trust]] said that the phone calls were a "deplorable intrusion with no editorial justification."<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationDeplorable">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=Jonathan Ross and Russell Brand's lewd calls to actor Andrew Sachs were a "deplorable intrusion with no editorial justification", the BBC Trust has said.}}</ref> The Trust found that the existing BBC guidelines should have been sufficient to have prevented the incident, and that the "very offensive" programme should "never have been recorded."<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationFailures"/> It found the failures lay in mistakes made by BBC editorial and compliance management.<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationFailures">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=Referring to the incident, BBC trustee Richard Tait said three main failures were made – in exercising editorial control; in following established compliance systems and a failure of judgment in taking editorial decisions. He said the furore could have been avoided if BBC management had followed the corporation's editorial guidelines. "It is a catalogue of editorial and management failures," he added. "It was a very offensive programme which should never have been recorded. Once the offensive phone call was made, the recording should have stopped and senior management alerted," he said. }}</ref> The Trust gave its backing to the BBC's response to the incident and Ross' 12-week suspension.<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationBBCActions">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=However, he said the trust considered the BBC's response to the controversy to have been appropriate. Asked if any further action would be taken against Jonathan Ross, Sir Michael said: "We are very clear that the director general has taken the right action with respect to Jonathan Ross."}}</ref>
Echoing the findings of the BBC Trust, the BBC itself stated the incident was a "very, very serious failure in a radio programme where editorial judgement was exercised that seriously let the BBC down."<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationDeplorableBBCResponse">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=The BBC said in a statement "It was a very, very serious failure in a radio programme where editorial judgement was exercised that seriously let the BBC down," }}</ref>
The Trust also criticised Brand's "so-called apology" of 25 October, and the staff of [[Chris Moyles]]' BBC Radio 1 show for also breaching BBC guidelines for comments by Brand in an interview on the morning of 21 October at a time when children were likely to be listening.<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationDeplorableBrandActions">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=Mr Tait said the offence of the original broadcast was compounded by Russell Brand's appearance on Chris Moyles' Radio 1 show on 21 October. He said this discussion, in itself, was also in breach of editorial guidelines in respect of privacy, offence and the fact it was broadcast at a time when children were likely to be listening. Mr Tait added that the trust considered Brand's "unacceptable, so-called apology" broadcast on Radio 2 on 25 October "exacerbated the intrusion into privacy and the offence". The trust ... recommended ... that there should be tighter controls on shows made by companies owned by their performers. Brand's show was made by his own firm.}}</ref> The Trust recommended tighter controls for programmes such as Brand's, made by companies owned by their performers.<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationDeplorableBrandActions"/> Long-term effects of the controversy would include the setting up of a register of high-risk programmes.<ref name="BBC21Nov2008NoJustificationDeplorableRiskResgister">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7741322.stm|title= 'No justification' for Brand show|publisher= [[BBC]]|date= 21 November 2008|accessdate= 21 November 2008|quote=Steps taken to ensure there is no repeat of the incident include creating a register of high-risk programmes.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
