==Further reading== {{refbegin|30em}} * {{cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article5023135.ece|title=Transcript: 'offensive' Brand and Ross calls|work=[[The Times]]|date=27 October 2008 | location=London | accessdate=23 May 2010 |first1=Charles |last1=Bremner |first2=David |last2=Robertson}} * {{cite news|title=Jonathan Ross and Russell Brand: past controversies|author=Nicole Martin|date=29 October 2008|url=http://telegraph.co.uk./news/3280359/Jonathan-Ross-and-Russell-Brand-past-controversies.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} * {{cite news|title=Ross and Brand, the bigger picture|author=Lord Fowler|authorlink=Norman Fowler|work=[[The Times]]|location=London|date=30 October 2008|url=http://timesonline.co.uk./tol/comment/letters/article5040972.ece}} * {{cite news|author=Jack Straw|authorlink=Jack Straw|title=The issues over standards at the BBC|work=[[Lancashire Telegraph]]|date=30 October 2008|url=http://lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/comment/3804407.The_issues_over_standards_at_the_BBC/|publisher=Newsquest Media Group}} * {{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk./blogs/theeditors/2008/10/open_and_shut_case.html |author= Rod McKenzie |publisher= BBC |title= Open and shut case? |date= 29 October 2008 |accessdate= 29 October 2008}} *{{cite web |title= And if Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross had been newspaper journalists? |website= journalism.co.uk |date= 30 October 2008 |url= http://www.journalism.co.uk/6/articles/532679.php |accessdate= 30 October 2008 |author= Martin Moore |publisher= Mousetrap Media Ltd}} * {{cite news |author=Mark Lawson|work=[[The Guardian]] |title= Welcome to the Blander Broadcasting Corporation |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |date=30 October 2008 |url=http://guardian.co.uk./commentisfree/2008/oct/30/bbc-jonathan-ross-russell-brand}} * {{cite news |author= [[India Knight]] |work= [[The Times]] |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/columnists/india_knight/article5062837.ece?Submitted=true |title= Pity the women who come within range of Brand and Ross |location= London |date= 2 November 2008 | accessdate= 23 May 2010}} {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/bsp/hi/pdfs/03_04_09_russelbrand.pdf Ofcom ruling on the incident]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=March 2016}} {{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Infobox film | name = Wrong Side of Town | image = Wrong Side of Town .jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[David DeFalco]] | producer = David DeFalco
Jason Hewitt
Carsten H.W. Lorenz | writer = David DeFalco | starring = [[Rob Van Dam]]
[[Dave Batista| David Bautista]] | music = [[Jim Kaufman]] | cinematography = Thomas Lembcke | editing = Andrew Drazek
Ezra Gould
Donald Ray Washington | studio = Films in Motion | distributor = Grindstone Entertainment Group | released = {{film date|2010|2|23}} | runtime = 88 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Wrong Side of Town''''' is a 2010 American [[action film]] written, produced and directed by [[David DeFalco]], and scored by [[Jim Kaufman]], and starring [[Rob Van Dam]] and [[Dave Bautista]]. The film was released on [[direct-to-video|direct-to-DVD]] in the United States on February 23, 2010. ==Plot== Bobby Kalinowski (Rob Van Dam), is a former [[United States Navy SEALs|Navy Seal]] enjoys a peaceful life as a [[landscape]] [[architect]] in [[Louisiana]] with his family. After receiving an invitation from new neighbors Clay Freeman (Edrick Browne) and Elise Freeman (Ava Santana), they go out for a night on the town to a famous club. The evening soon takes a turn for the worse when Bobby gets into a conflict with one of the club owners, named Ethan Bordas (Ross Britz). In the middle of the conflict, Ethan accidentally falls and is stabbed by his own knife, while fighting with Bobby, who was defending his wife. Seeking revenge, Ethan's father Seth Bordas (Jerry Katz), previously thought to be his older brother, puts a $100,000 [[bounty (reward)|bounty]] on Bobby's head. Also making matters difficult, Bobby is unable to receive help from the law, for Seth has Clay Freeman, and a corrupt police sergeant, working for him. Now Bobby must survive and escape Louisiana while being hunted by criminals, corrupt law, and many others in the city. To protect his family and neighbors, Bobby decides to separate himself from them and goes to his Navy Seal colleague Big Ronnie (David Bautista) (or known as B.R.) for help. B.R. initially refuses, deciding to take the bounty, but later changes his mind and helps Bobby. Seth targets Bobby’s family and kidnaps his 16-year-old daughter Brianna (Brooke Frost). However, Bobby ends up fighting and killing Seth and his henchmen with B.R.'s help, and rescues his daughter. ==Cast== * [[Rob Van Dam]] as Bobby Kalinowski * [[Dave Bautista]] as Big Ronnie (B.R.) * Lara Grice as Dawn Kalinowski * Edrick Browne as Clay Freeman * Ava Santana as Elise Freeman * [[Stormy Daniels]] as Stormy * [[Randal Reeder]] as Trouble * Jerry Katz as Seth Bordas * Louis Herthum as Briggs * Brooke Frost as Brianna Kalinowski * [[Ja Rule|Ja Rule a.k.a. Jeffrey Atkins]] as Razor * [[Viscera (wrestler)|Nelson Frazier, Jr.]] as Animal * Damon Lipari as Nicky * Scott Schwartz as Deacon * [[David DeFalco]] as Demon * Marrese Crump as Markus * [[Omarion|Omarion a.k.a. Omari Grandberry]] as Stash * Quess a.k.a. Brian Wakefield as Dawg * Ross Britz as Ethan Bordas * "Big Dog" Ramar Jenkins as Big Dog * Carsten H.W. Lorenz as Cab Driver * Anthony M. Frederick as Detective Hernandez * Gabriela Ostos as Abusive Woman * J. Omar Castro as Cop ==Production== It is set and filmed at [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] and [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]] on January 18 and February 21, 2009. ==Home media== On February 23, 2010, DVD was released by [[Lions Gate Entertainment|Lionsgate]] in the United States in [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]]. DVD was released in Region 2 in the United Kingdom on 15 March 2010, it was distributed by [[Entertainment One]]. ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1431191}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wrong Side Of Town}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:2010s action films]] [[Category:2010 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:American action films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Jim Kaufman]] [[Category:Films directed by David DeFalco]] [[Category:Films set in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films set in Louisiana]] [[Category:Professional wrestling-related media]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=August 2016}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2016}} }}
'''Zig Zag''' is a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] children's programming block broadcast daily on [[RTP2]] and [[RTP1]] from Portugal. It airs programming that is targeted for young people (children and teenagers) from ages 3–17. It airs daily on the weekdays from 07:00 to 11:15 WET, and again later on in the day from 16:00 to 20:05 WET. It airs programming in Portuguese.
== Broadcast Area == As many other RTP Television Stations, Zig Zag airs internationally in different countries. Note that all of its programming still airs in European Portuguese.
=== North America === RTP2 ZigZag airs in North America, as part of its international broadcast. * [[United States|United States of America]] * [[Canada]]
=== South America === * [[Brazil]] * [[Colombia]] * [[Ecuador]] * [[Venezuela]] * [[Guyana]] * [[Suriname]] * [[Uruguay]] * [[Chile]] * [[Argentina]] * [[Peru]]
=== Africa === See [[RTP África]], and [[Portuguese-speaking African countries|Portuguese Africa]]. * [[Cape Verde]] * [[Mozambique]] * [[São Tomé and Principe]] * [[Angola]] * [[Guinea-Bissau]] * [[Equatorial Guinea]]
=== Asia === * [[Macau]] * [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Asia|Others]]
=== Europe === * [[Portugal]] * [[List of sovereign states and dependent territories in Europe|Others]]
=== Oceania === * [[Australia]] * [[New Zealand]] * [[Pacific Islands]]
